fields.headline: The best broken equipment scene
fields.standfirst: The perfect storm
fields.trailText: The perfect storm
fields.body:
As the storm gets worse, Billy Tyne (George Clooney), captain of the Andrea Gail, attempts to steer the ship out of trouble. Having lost radio contact, Bobby Shatford (Mark Wahlberg) has been outside trying to repair the antenna. He struggles into the cabin.

"It's gone."

Tyne shakes his head.

"No antenna, no radio. We're back in the 19th century."

The two men stare out into the storm.

"Skip, you wanna call it quits? Turn around?"

"What do you think?"

"I think she's a hell of a boat."

Grinning, Tyne turns to Shatford.

"With a hell of a crew."

"And a hell of a skipper."

Outside the cabin, a metal chain snaps, sending equipment flying across the deck. Tyne continues his attempts to steer the ship through the storm.

"Alright Gloucester - we're coming home."

Suddenly, a huge gust sends the chain and anchor smashing through the cabin window, destroying yet more equipment.

Tyne turns once more to Shatford.

"Take the wheel."

He steps outside, into the storm...

See also: 2001, Back To The Future, Young Frankenstein, Donnie Brasco

Don't see also: Fair Game

Pointless trivia: For its climactic scenes, The Perfect Storm used the largest water tank in the history of film-making.

fields.headline: Lastminute buys French rival
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com yesterday made its first buy since its troubled flotation when it announced that it had acquired French online travel company Degriftour Group for £58.9m in cash and shares.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com yesterday made its first buy since its troubled flotation when it announced that it had acquired French online travel company Degriftour Group for £58.9m in cash and shares.

The British company paid for the deal by dipping into its cash reserves for £27.1m and issuing 19.7m new shares at 162p to provide the balance.

Co-founder Martha Lane Fox said the deal would give Lastminute a market-leading position in France which otherwise would have taken two or three years to build and was expected to help the e-commerce firm move to profitability earlier than forecast.

"Many of the analysts are bringing forward their targets for when we break even by six to nine months, to the middle of 2002," Ms Lane Fox said. "We have been offered the chance to look at perhaps 50 companies in the last few months and we believe [Degriftour] is the nearest thing to our business model. It's the perfect opportunity."

Analysts broadly welcomed the move, saying that Lastminute was buying an established business with a positive cashflow and for a relatively cheap price. Heidi Fitzpatrick, analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "Lastminute is doing exactly the right thing, building scale quickly and buying market share at what looks like an extremely cheap price."

Another analyst questioned whether shareholders who bought in at the float price of 380p would be happy to see new shares issued at less than half the original price, and whether this deal would lead to further acquisitions around Europe.

Degriftour, managed by Pierre Alzon, was set up nine years ago and is France's largest e-travel company, with 50% market share.

In the year to the March 31 Degriftour generated a transaction value of £50.3m and a gross profit of £9.1m from a customer base of 93,468. Margins were 18% compared to Lastminute's 10%.

Lastminute has £118m cash in the bank following the acquisition, and Ms Lane Fox said the deal will lead to huge cost savings. Lastminute shares edged up 3.5p to 165.5p.

Degriftour is essentially an conventional travel company which is evolving into a web-based business. In the three months to June 30, 60% of total transaction value came from items bought on the web.

Ms Lane Fox believes that proportion will grow, particularly after Lastminute's other products are introduced to the Degriftour site.

The French firm is 78% owned by founder Francis Reverse. He and the other shareholders have agreed to hold their new Lastminute.com shares for at least 18 months.

Lastminute has said that it would entertain acquisitions as long as they made strategic sense.

Rival online travel agency E-bookers yesterday claimed Lastminute's move to buy Degriftour reinforced its own belief that the only way net companies with European ambitions are going to realise them is through acquisition.

fields.headline: Better the devil you know
fields.standfirst:
Tom Service sees Christoph von Dohnanyi launch the international festival in spectacular style

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Tom Service sees Christoph von Dohnanyi launch the international festival in spectacular style
fields.body:
The purgatorial power of Berlioz's teeming choral-orchestral hybrid, La Damnation de Faust, is a spectacular way to begin any festival. But with conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi and the Cleveland Orchestra, a cast of soloists like Bryn Terfel, Jennifer Larmore and Vinson Cole, and a small army of singers, it proved a suitably stunning curtain-raiser for the international festival - and a star-studded christening for the newly refurbished Usher Hall.

Inspired by Goethe's definitive romantic tragedy, Berlioz's invention in La Damnation encompasses everything from celestial choirs to drunken mobs and bloodthirsty demons. Although designed as a concert work, the piece is really an opera for the imagination. The unearthly colours that Berlioz draws from his huge orchestral resources and massed ranks of choirs are as vividly theatrical as any 19th-century horror opera. Yet somehow the oratorio format makes the work seem even more dramatic than it would be in the theatre. In passages like the final Pandemonium, with its chorus of the damned singing in an unknown tongue, and the Princes of Darkness ruled by Mephistopheles' diabolical magic, Berlioz's score completely transcends its function as a purely musical concert piece. Instead, the music's immediacy is an assault on all the senses, suggesting a kaleidoscope of images that would be impossible to realise on the stage.

But the score needs more than mere brute force if Berlioz's visions of mortal and immortal life are to jump off the page as they should. Von Dohnanyi has been superbly convincing in realising the fantasy of Berlioz's orchestration, yet making individual scenes serve the ends of the whole drama. For all that the concluding Ride to the Abyss had a glorious, twisted grandeur, it also provided a dramatic contrast to the pastoral reverie of the earlier Dance of the Sylphes. The special magnificence of the Cleveland Orchestra's woodwind section brought to life the otherworldly choreography of Berlioz's filigree spirits.

At the centre of the performance was Vinson Cole's Faust. Unencumbered by a score, he was by turns an innocent fool and selfish, helpless oaf, tormented by Mephistopheles' relentless pursuit of his soul. Cole caught Faust's world-weariness especially successfully in the first part, perfectly portraying Berlioz's conception of the philosophical and narcissistic side of his anti-hero.

Bryn Terfel was magnetic as Mephistopheles. From his first entry, accompanied by a spectral crash of cymbals and shimmering strings, Terfel's presence commanded the stage just as his Mephistopheles led Faust inexorably to his doom. Terfel was the ideal vocal foil for Cole's Faust. Where Cole emphasised the languorous lyricism of his part, Terfel was chillingly assertive and uncompromising, even in the deft virtuosity of the Song of the Flea.

Neal Davies made for a jovial Brander; Jennifer Larmore's Marguerite, however, was less sharply focused than the other solo roles, even if her set pieces in the third part were beguiling. But choruses from Cleveland and Edinburgh, along with the RSNO Junior Chorus, were mightily impressive in their roles as peasants, students and spirits, ensuring the supernatural success of Berlioz's epic.

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers attack Standard
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A fresh battle over the future of Standard Life loomed yesterday after a Scottish businessman announced that he was launching a new attempt to force the mutual insurer to convert and make windfall payments to members.
fields.body:
A fresh battle over the future of Standard Life loomed yesterday after a Scottish businessman announced that he was launching a new attempt to force the mutual insurer to convert and make windfall payments to members.

Gordon Hart, chairman of the net-based Members' Rights Campaign, is meeting with the firm today to discuss its aims. He claims that the 2.3m member-policyholders could receive payouts averaging almost £8,000 if it were to float on the stock market.

The new challenge to Standard Life's status as Europe's biggest mutual insurer comes less than two months after it defeated a conversion attempt led by a Monaco-based Australian, Fred Woollard.

Mr Hart, who has already targeted two other mutual in surers with some success, is calling for policyholders to be given an independently audited and impartial estimate of the windfall they would be likely to receive, and that this should be followed by a referendum early next year.

Mr Hart, a director of a telecoms firm, said he believes Standard Life understated Standard Life's value in the last conversion campaign.

The insurer endorsed a £12bn valuation of the group in the anti-conversion literature it sent out to policyholders and said about half of members would receive windfalls of less than £2,500.

This conflicted with Mr Woollard's estimate of windfalls averaging £5,000-£6,300 to qualifying policyholders.

Following a bitterly fought battle, Standard Life announced on June 27 that only 45.7% of members had voted for demutualisation.

Mr Hart, of Hamilton, said his group estimated the value at about £18bn, which would mean average windfalls of £7,800. Respected independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet has valued the company at £16bn, while other estimates had gone as high as £20bn, he said.

"We believe the recent campaign by Standard Life failed to reveal the true facts about demutualisation, and that the board did not act in the best interests of members. Many members would like a fair and unbiased investigation into the whole mutual issue, something that the £10m spent by the board failed to do."

More than 500,000 policyholders have underperforming endowment policies, said Mr Hart, who is a long-term policyholder himself. He is seeking donations from policyholders as well as from larger investors. His website features advertising from book and CD retailer Amazon and online auctioneer QXL.com.

The insurer said on February 9 that policies bought after that date would not be eligible for a windfall for a period of at least three years.

It has not taken any other action against carpetbaggers - its rules still allow any resolution to be proposed to a special meeting providing it has at least 50 supporters.

Hart back on prowl

After the failed attempt by carpetbaggers led by Monaco-based Fred Wollard to demutalise Standard Life, Scotland's biggest mutual life insurer thought it was safe. Until Gordon Hart turned up.

Mr Hart is chairman of the internet-based Members' Rights Campaign, a group claiming to fight for the rights of policyholders of mutual financial institutions and "find out what the members really want". What he appears to want is to secure the conversion of Standard Life into a PLC, unlocking windfalls he estimated could average almost £8,000.

The 50-year-old father of two can already claim one scalp in the form of Friends Provident, Britain's third largest mutual life insurer, which announced in May that it intends to convert to a PLC, days after coming under attack from Mr Hart's Friends Provident Vote Campaign group. Another of his targets, Scottish Provident, has agreed to review its mutual status after being targeted by another of the groups he leads, the Scottish Provident Members Alliance Group.

Mr Hart, of Hamilton, who is a director of a telecoms company, denies he is a carpetbagger - Members' Rights Campaign is, he says, a group "for all mutual members who believe in democracy and truth". He says he is no speculator, having been a Standard Life policyholder for two decades.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Susan and Janice

fields.headline: Susan and Janice
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Over the Road 2
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Over the Road 2
****
fields.body:
Subtitled I Hate My Sister, this witty show is proof that sibling rivalry can be entertaining. Janice Phayre (the unwilling tomboy) and Susan Earl (think pink horror Maxine in Coronation Street) aren't actually sisters, but understand that complex relationship well enough to make sharply-observed comedy. They are a hail of miniskirts, appalling handbags and dynamite dialogue set to a chintzy backdrop of 80s pop (Duran, Spandau).

Once the Irish duo expand the theme to the religious sisterhood, things really take off. "What words sum up how we're feeling now?" asks the demure Sister Josephine. Her bile-faced partner spits: "Hell and damnation!"

This catty double act offers some evil one-liners that only occasionally touch crudeness. It's especially funny finding out what girls whispering in the back pew of catholic churches say about choir boys. Towards the end even the comedians have difficulty keeping straight faces.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Robert Newman
fields.standfirst:
Assembly Rooms Music Hall
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Assembly Rooms Music Hall
****
fields.body:
There are two Rob Newmans. One is the iconic, Byron-beautiful lad who told beery jokes at Wembley with David Baddiel. The other - the loftier "Robert" - is the bloated and somehow damaged figure who lectures us on environmental politics. Both alter egos are in evidence here.

Newman speaks about his younger self as a "backstreet driver of the psyche" and refers darkly to mental illness. The fallout from Baddiel has obviously transformed him, but when Newman is forced into delivering saucy monologues from the Mary Whitehouse Experience, you wonder if he will ever be able to move on completely.

The troubled comic's big dilemma is how to sustain politics when crowds are yearning for beer and fag jokes. He pushes the crowd as far as he can go (discussing the Reclaim the Streets marches, the Paris Commune) before reining them in again with a killer punchline. This generally works because Newman is a terrific storyteller, and has become a master of the educationally hilarious one-liner. A GM food mutated by pesticides, for example, is "the Shaun Ryder of the botanical world".

His challenge now is to make the politics as memorable as the punchlines. He takes a huge gamble by closing the set with a message about corporate fear of massed action that contains no humour at all, but Newman is almost alone now in teaching us that comedy can be about much more than laughter.

Ends tomorrow. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

webTitle: Big banks join Reuters for online forex venture

fields.headline: Big banks join Reuters for online forex venture
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Three leading banks - Citibank, Chase Investment Bank and Deutsche Bank - are teaming up with the news and information provider, Reuters, to develop a company to deliver foreign exchange dealing services.
fields.body:
The $1,500bn a day international foreign exchange market is about to be turned into an internet battleground. Three leading banks - Citibank, Chase Investment Bank and Deutsche Bank - are teaming up with the news and information provider, Reuters, to develop a company to deliver foreign exchange dealing services.

That will put them in direct competition with FX Alliance - a 13-strong banking consortium that revealed its net forex plans earlier this year.

The three banks and Reuters declined to comment on the scheme, which is being put together under the codename Rose. Banking sources in London, however, said that although the project has still to be finalised it is expected to be launched in the first quarter of next year and will offer a full range of services by the third quarter of the year.

The creation of rival online forex services highlights the growing trend towards the use of the internet for the trading of currency products.

Industry sources say that customers increasingly want to use a single platform rather than a raft of systems each owned by a different bank.

The crucial question for the rivals is whether there is a big enough market for two online services, whether they will be able to offer different products and services or whether the rivalry will come down to price.

"They could end up specialising in different things but if they don't differentiate themselves like this it will come down to prices.

"In the short term, Citibank, Deutsche and Chase could be very aggressive on the pricing," said one source in the banking industry.

The plans for FX Alliance, which is expected to be up and running either later this year or early next, were announced in June.

Initially its line-up was Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs, HSBC, JP Morgan, Bank of America and UBS Warburg. However, another six banks including Dresdner Kleinwort Benson and the Royal Bank of Scotland signed up last month.

Citibank, Deutsche and Chase are all believed to have been involved in the original talks over FX Alliance.

According to another banking source there were talks between the heads of 12 banks in New York.

"There were discussions and it got to the point where things had gone far enough for them to say that people either had to declare a conflict of interest or walk away. Citi, Deutsche and Chase walked away."

****
fields.body:
Hlynur does "the nothing kind of nothing" with his life - unless you count surfing the internet for porn and masturbating to aerobics videos as worthwhile pastimes. Neither his mother, his erstwhile girlfriend nor the exotic Lola - who brings flamenco and Latin passion to the cold, brutally beautiful Iceland - do.

Yet Hlynur - played with just the right amount of cuteness and fury by Hilmir Snaer Gudnason - perseveres with his slackerdom until events force him to re-evaluate his passivity. His girlfriend pregnant, he and Lola have wild firecracker sex as New Year dawns; shortly after his mother steps out of the closet, declaring her love for Lola, the excellent Victoria Abril.

This is quite a debut for director Baltasar Kormakur. Comedy blends with tender poignancy in a gentle, quirky film that encompasses the best elements of romantic comedy, farce and generation X movies, deftly covering everything from lesbian parenting to masculinity in crisis on the way.

From the squeak of Hlynur's bed mid-masturbation to the rat-a-tat-tat of flamenco shoe on wooden floor, rhythm is at the heart of 101 Reykjavik, while Damon Albarn's contribution to the soundtrack lends resonance to every scene of sweaty parties and mountains in snowstorms, without ever overpowering the images. It is just as a movie soundtrack should be.

Skirting cliche, predictability and self-indulgence, this is a tight, sparse film with a big heart. There are no easy answers and a significant amount of soul searching goes on alongside sublime comic moments. 101 Reykjavik is something special.

Tonight at the Filmhouse, and August 21 at the Cameo. Box office: 0131-620 8030.

fields.headline: Members of the Cleveland Orchestra
fields.standfirst:
Queen's Hall
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Queen's Hall
***
fields.body:
The Cleveland Orchestra's sound is one of luxurious confidence, and that was certainly present in this programme of chamber works by Mendelssohn, Poulenc and Beethoven. Most memorable were moments of solo brilliance, such as horn-player Richard King's deliciously raucous contributions in the finale of Beethoven's Septet, or bassoonist John Clouser's exquisite cadenza in the first movement of Poulenc's Sextet for winds and piano.

Mendelssohn's Octet for strings did not cohere convincingly. Led by the Cleveland Orchestra's concertmaster William Preucil, the ensemble tried to generate a furious momentum, but were unbalanced. However, Preucil's expressiveness, veering from stark, vibrato-less bowing to glutinous portamento, was exciting, and contributed to a moment of intense drama when he snapped a string in the closing paragraphs of the first movement.

Intriguing though it was to hear a Beethovenian performance of one of Mendelssohn's most idiomatic chamber pieces, it was the Cleveland players' flowing, gentle - even Mendelssohnian - account of Beethoven's Septet that showed them at their decorous best. Even in Poulenc's quicksilver Sextet, low-key restraint and good manners dominated over neo-classical wit and interpretative insight.

fields.headline: Bring on the challenges
fields.standfirst:
Millennium Youth Day
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Millennium Youth Day
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Music for young people - new works for a new generation of performers - is one of the themes of Proms 2000. The most spectacular showcase for this wealth of upcoming talent was Saturday's double-decker event, which brought together all of the country's national youth-music ensembles as part of the UK-wide Millennium Festival. The afternoon concert featured the National Children's Orchestra, Wind Ensemble, Chamber Orchestra and Choir, while the evening programme found spots for the National Youth Choir, Wind Orchestra, Jazz Orchestra, Brass Band, and the National Youth Orchestra itself, with a performance of Walton's Belshazzar's Feast conducted by Paul Daniel to round it off.

The Walton was electrifying, just the kind of special performance needed to crown a celebration like this. With the NYO up to its formidable full strength - septuple woodwind, and oodles of horns and trumpets - as well as the National Youth Brass Band to supply the extra instruments that Walton drafts in for the climactic sections, there was no shortage of sheer weight. The National Youth Choir demonstrated that writing which can test many an adult choral society holds no terrors for them, while Thomas Allen, the baritone soloist, timed his rhetoric with the theatricality of a seasoned stage campaigner. Daniel also brought the latent operatic potential of the work to the fore, stealthily pacing the increase in tension through the opening section, giving the explosions of rhythmic energy edge and menace, and bringing a huge adrenaline rush to the final rounds of rejoicing.

The first half of that evening concert, though, had been a good deal less convincing, not through any lack of expertise among the performers - the wealth of instrumental and vocal talent on display was consistently awesome - but because the premieres from Philip Wilby and Paul Hart were so bland and unrewarding. Young musicians don't need to be patronised with new music as anodyne as this. Wilby's A New World Dancing sets sections of speeches by Desmond Tutu for solo mezzo (Yvonne Howard), chorus and wind band in a style that has characterised the stagnation of English church music for half a century, while Hart's Out of Hamelin, a BBC commission for the National Youth Jazz Orchestra, tacks a sequence of jazzy cliches around the story of the Pied Piper, without any striking ideas but far too much padding. The brilliant young soloists of NYJO deserved something far grittier.

webTitle: Dixons deal sees Freeserve and Gameplay link up

fields.headline: Dixons deal sees Freeserve and Gameplay link up
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Hopes that Freeserve might again become a bid target faded yesterday when its parent firm Dixons announced a deal with online gaming company Gameplay.com that appeared to make the internet service provider a more integral part of the retailer's business model.
fields.body:
Hopes that Freeserve might again become a bid target faded yesterday when its parent firm Dixons announced a deal with online gaming company Gameplay.com that appeared to make the internet service provider a more integral part of the retailer's business model.

Dixons said it was working with Gameplay on a number of ways to exploit opportunities in the computer games market by using its high street stores and the internet through Freeserve. Dixons could end up owning 22.5% of Gameplay under the terms of the deal.

Analysts interpreted the news as a sign that Dixons now sees Freeserve as more central to its ongoing business than previously and may not seek to sell off its 80% stake. The future of Freeserve has been the subject of speculation since June when negotiations to sell the company to German rival T-Online for £6bn collapsed.

"This deal does not preclude Dixons selling down a significant stake if the right buyer comes along, but probably does mean that the chances of a complete divorce between the two companies and a bid for the quoted minority becomes a slightly more complicated exercise," said Simon Irwin, analyst at BNP.

Freeserve shares fell 4p to 262p as bid hopes receded, while Dixons slipped 7p to 238p. Gameplay shares rose 10p to 227.5p.

Dixons could eventually end up owning up to 22.5% of Gameplay, under the terms of the agreement which will see Dixons' @jakarta computer games shops rebranded Gameplay, and Gameplay operating Freeserve's interactive game channel on an exclusive basis for four years.

Dixons and Gameplay's British games buying operations will be consolidated leading to economies of scale. Freeserve will take a share of revenue from each game sold through its site.

"This deal illustrates the combined distribution power of Dixons and Freeserve," said chief executive John Pluthero.

Gameplay, run by chief executive Mark Bernstein, is one of the fastest growing online games retailers in Europe. BT and BSkyB have already taken stakes in Gameplay giving it strong telecoms and digital television partners. By partnering with Dixons, Gameplay gains a high street "bricks and mortar" presence and access to the retailer's customer base.

Mr Bernstein said that while most games are sold in boxes in the high street, in a few years time they are likely to be sold directly over the net.

"The partnership with Dixons will help us to develop stronger relationship with games publishers and developers," he said.

fields.headline: Rising to the top
fields.trailText: 15 August: Why you should always ask for more money when a new employer offers you a starting salary at the low end of the job's pay scale.
fields.body:
The problem

I have been offered a job as an editorial assistant on a website which, in the interview, I was told would pay £18-20,000. Then when they offered me the job they said I would be starting on £18,000. Should I still negotiate for something higher?

The solution

Yes, of course! Having said that, to have a good argument, you would have to have convincing reasons as to why you deserve a salary at the higher band. Normally, when a salary band is advertised in a recruitment advert, the more a candidate fits the person specification, the higher they can expect their salary to be within the offered band. Naturally, most employers try to get away with offering as low a salary as they think they can get away with - and some even offer a lower salary as a starting point for negotiation.

So, if you think you are worthy of more, go ahead and ask. You will need to explain that you fit the person specification perfectly, or that you excel in a particular area: for example, you have more experience than they require, or higher qualifications. If you are convinced that you deserve to start right at the top range, go for it and ask for £20,000. Chances are, they will compromise and offer you £19,000.

Remember, you are in the best position to ask for a pay-rise since they have openly indicated a confidence in your ability to do the job - if they weren't convinced they wouldn't have offered it you. Also, bear in mind that whatever you manage to negotiate will have a knock-on effect for your entire future, since your current salary is often used as a starting point in negotiations for your next position. So, go for it.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: El Dorado
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance One
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance One

****
fields.body:
Welcome to the New World, where, fantastical creatures take you on a journey into the mad dreams of both the Spanish Conquistadors and our own greedy fantasies. This show, a controlled and imaginative piece of Buffoon theatre inspired by the work of Jacques Le Coq, is as close as you can get to winning the lottery on the Edinburgh fringe. Although not everyone will warm to its stylistic quirks, it is impossible not to be drawn into this dream world where tales of conquerors are told by outcasts and mad exploits are narrated by the insane. It is both absurdly heroic and deflating.

There is no through narrative, merely a series of scenes of torture, murder and death recreated with the greatest good humour, as the Conquistadors chase gold in the name of God and kill for something that doesn't even exist. At the end God proves himself to be as slippery as a wet fish and the only loot there is comes from the audience.

This is a very clever show, a rich, bejewelled thing that exposes the folly of human greed and our wasted dreams.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Hey Gringo!
fields.standfirst:
Komedia @ Southside
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Komedia @ Southside
****
fields.body:
A bloke stands on a bare stage telling us about a holiday he took in Chile more than 15 years ago. It sounds like the definition of dullness, but an hour and 20 minutes later you are yearning for more.

Quite what makes Peter Searles such a riveting story teller is hard to put a finger on. Maybe it's the way he drops in wonderfully surreal details - hundreds of poor people shuffling along on one shoe to Pinochet's birthday parade (they only get the other one after they've sung "Happy Birthday Papa" to him) - or the fact that his tales never quite go the way you expect. He loves and leaves the beautiful girl Elizabeth and her child to the tender mercies of the secret police and ends up unwittingly becoming a hero of Chile's most famous eco-warrior guerrilla raid.

All the usual political tourist stuff is here, as naive Gringo assumptions are trumped by the strange compromises of living a "normal life" in Chile. There is also the weirdness of the place being a little bit of England, or at least Europe. Forget the death squads, the most chilling episode was an evening he spent with upper class friends who idolised Mrs Thatcher. How the blood froze.

Till August 27. Box office: 0131-667 2212.

webTitle: Sainsbury adds cars to its supermarket shelves

fields.headline: Sainsbury adds cars to its supermarket shelves
fields.trailText: A supermarket war over cars looked poised to break out last night after Sainsbury introduced a scheme to sell new vehicles and Tesco said it was considering a similar plan.
fields.body:
A supermarket war over cars looked poised to break out last night after Sainsbury introduced a scheme to sell new vehicles and Tesco said it was considering a similar plan.

Sainsbury is taking its car sales to all its stores after a successful pilot scheme in Scotland and the north of England. Customers will be able to choose from over 3,500 models by picking up a leaflet and placing an order by phone.

The food retailer claims the main benefits are not having to deal with car salesmen and a special financing package being run through Sainbury's Bank, a joint venture between the stores group and the Bank of Scotland.

Cars are sold under two- or three-year agreements with customers being able to choose at the end of that period whether to pay off the remaining sum or return the car.

Customers can put down a £215 deposit and pay from £152 a month. A Peugeot 206 hatchback 1.1L would cost £10,827.74 to buy after three years using an annual percentage borrowing rate of 10.9%.

Sainsbury claims to be the first supermarket group to enter the car market but Tesco said it too had been weighing up the advantages. Like Sainsbury, Tesco has moved from food retailing into the sale of petrol and banking services. A spokeswoman said: "We have been looking at the market for over a year and are seriously considering selling cars."

webTitle: Internet share deals down by a third

fields.headline: Internet share deals down by a third
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: The number of online share deals plunged by a third in the period April to June after the slump in hi-tech shares prompted many private investors to scale down their trading activities, figures out today will show.
fields.body:
The number of online share deals plunged by a third in the period April to June after the slump in hi-tech shares prompted many private investors to scale down their trading activities, figures out today will show.

Research by ComPeer shows that 648,000 trading orders were placed over the net in the second quarter from 930,000 in the first quarter. Justin Urquhart Stewart at Barclays Stockbrokers said the drop in volumes was "going to cause real pain for some brokers".

The past few months have seen the launch of a string of new online share-dealing services, with internet bank Egg and Virgin among the companies joining the already crowded market. Mr Urquhart Stewart predicted there would be a shake-out, saying: "There is going to be blood on the keyboards before the year is out."

The gloom of the latest figures is tempered by the news that the number of share-dealing accounts being opened is continuing to rise sharply.

The figures may indicate that many of the small investors who piled into the market earlier this year have cut down on their trading activities after suffering losses.

Stock exchange figures show that the average number of transactions (both online and offline) rose to 134,000 in January, hitting a peak of 180,000 a day during parts of March. Since then, volumes have dropped, with May seeing just 104,000 transactions per day.

The figures follow a report from investment bank JP Morgan which said Britain was lagging behind other European countries in numbers of active online private investors.

fields.headline: Returning to Vivaldi
fields.standfirst:
Orlando Plays Mad
BAC, London
**
fields.trailText:
Orlando Plays Mad
BAC, London
**
fields.body:
With Handel securely re- established at the heart of the operatic repertory, the next baroque growth area could well be Vivaldi. Cecilia Bartoli has already embarked on a one-woman crusade to show that his stage works, more than 20 of them extant, contain many vocal treasures, and full productions will surely follow. An attempt to revive his Orlando Finta Pazza (Orlando Plays Mad in this translation) launches this summer's opera season at BAC. Only the second of the three acts is staged this time; a full production is threatened for next year.

Director Bill Bankes-Jones and conductor Orlando Jopling have begun to prepare a performing edition from the surviving material in Venice, which lay unperformed after the failure of the initial run of performances in 1714. Bankes-Jones has made an English version of the text, and several numbers excised from the score before the premiere have been restored.

The plot may be complex, a typical baroque confection of disguises, cross-dressing and magic potions, in which the powers of the wicked sorceress Ersilla are eventually overcome by the heroic Orlando and his sidekick Brandimarte. But it's no more involved than many a Handel scenario - Ersilla is a potentially tragic figure rather like Handel's Alcina, for instance - and certainly deserves to be taken more seriously than Bankes-Jones's high-camp staging suggests. Playing everything for laughs, in Eurotrash costumes, this pantomime does nothing to articulate the drama or the characterisation, let alone explore the seriousness at the heart of the opera.

The tone of the evening is set by the first half, which prefaces the performance of the second act with an introduction to the opera by the conductor and director. It includes a number of set pieces from the first and third acts, linked by a commentary that is pitched at a Playschool level of fatuity, offering little illumination but plenty of irrelevant detail, and suggesting no more seriousness about the whole project than the production itself.

What saves the event from total banality is the quality of the music-making. Jopling conducts a period band with a good deal of energy, and the cast contains some fine performances, especially from the counter-tenors Stephen Wallace (definitely a young singer to watch) as the knight Grifone, and Christopher Robson as Brandimarte, as well as Arlene Rolph as Orgille. Their efforts, though, cannot disguise the apparent lack of real understanding of Vivaldi's operatic intentions, which undermines the whole project.

Further performances on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Box office: 020-7223 2223

Cecilia Bartoli has already embarked on a one-woman crusade to show that his stage works, more than 20 of them extant, contain many vocal treasures, and full productions will surely follow. An attempt to revive his Orlando Finta Pazza (Orlando Plays Mad in this translation) launches this summer's opera season at BAC. Only the second of the three acts is staged this time; a full production is threatened for next year. Director Bill Bankes-Jones and conductor Orlando Jopling have begun to prepare a performing edition from the surviving material in Venice, which lay unperformed after the failure of the initial run of performances in 1714. Bankes-Jones has made an English version of the text, and several numbers excised from the score before the premiere have been restored. The plot may be complex, a typical baroque confection of disguises, cross-dressing and magic potions, in which the powers of the wicked sorceress Ersilla are eventually overcome by the heroic Orlando and his sidekick Brandimarte. But it's no more involved than many a Handel scenario - Ersilla is a potentially tragic figure rather like Handel's Alcina, for instance - and certainly deserves to be taken more seriously than Bankes-Jones's high-camp staging suggests. Playing everything for laughs, in Eurotrash costumes, this pantomime does nothing to articulate the drama or the characterisation, let alone explore the seriousness at the heart of the opera. The tone of the evening is set by the first half, which prefaces the performance of the second act with an introduction to the opera by the conductor and director. It includes a number of set pieces from the first and third acts, linked by a commentary that is pitched at a Playschool level of fatuity, offering little illumination but plenty of irrelevant detail, and suggesting no more seriousness about the whole project than the production itself. What saves the event from total banality is the quality of the music-making. Jopling conducts a period band with a good deal of energy, and the cast contains some fine performances, especially from the counter-tenors Stephen Wallace (definitely a young singer to watch) as the knight Grifone, and Christopher Robson as Brandimarte, as well as Arlene Rolph as Orgille. Their efforts, though, cannot disguise the apparent lack of real understanding of Vivaldi's operatic intentions, which undermines the whole project. Further performances on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Box office: 020-7223 2223

fields.headline: Rock 'n' rehash
fields.standfirst:
The Delta 72
Wag Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Delta 72
Wag Club, London
***
fields.body:
"Listen children, we came here to give back a little of that soul magic." So speaks Gregg Foreman, lead singer of the Delta 72 and impassioned exponent of funk. And metal. And lowdown dirty rock'n'roll. The Delta 72 hail from Philadelphia and have made it their quest to take the old soul sound and drag it into the present. Using influences as diverse as the Small Faces and Royal Trux, the Rolling Stones and the MC5, they are the Spencer Davis Group as covered by Nirvana, tight Hammond sounds fused with raw, ear-bleeding power, just as likely to make you go out and smash something as they are to get you dancing. And Eminem thinks he's frightening.

This is a band on a mission from God, and as Gospel According to Huey P merges into The Doctor Is In, the service begins. A wiry rock'n'roll rebel with a dodgy haircut and fervent belief in the healing power of soul, Foreman stands at the edge of the stage, arms outstretched. As Mark Boyce makes his keyboards wail and pushes them dangerously towards the front of the stage, Foreman abandons his guitar, jumps off the stage and sings in a gruff, dark voice, surrounded by the crowd. Climbing on to the shoulders of a by-stander, eyes closed, he carries on singing, until his weary carrier finally throws him back on to the stage. Before you know it, he's leading us into a "soul clap". This is late 60s soul, US punk style with a touch of old school showbiz thrown in.

It's just a pity that while the performance is original, the music is a bit secondhand. While Jason Kourkounis's ragged, soaring guitars, Adam Cothren's percussion and the heavy bass of Bruce Reckahn Jnr are a heady, thumping slice of rock, the Delta 72 are too enamoured of the past to let go of it completely. Each song is sweetly dedicated to a legend - from Ronnie Lane to Booker T and the MGs - and the songs are peppered with recognisable riffs that skip into each other like a scratch CD of Great Rock Moments. But as I Feel Fine and Why Is Not an Answer see the wah-wah guitars smudging and screeching all over the place, sounding fantastic as the sweat drips down the walls of the Wag, we've all been converted.

fields.headline: Row on pension delays
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government was under fire last night for dragging its feet over a much-called-for overhaul of the rules set up to protect the pension funds of bankrupt companies.
fields.body:
The government was under fire last night for dragging its feet over a much-called-for overhaul of the rules set up to protect the pension funds of bankrupt companies.

Industry sources accused the government of sitting on a detailed analysis of alternative schemes to rival the current minimum funding requirement (MFR) rules, which were set up after the Maxwell pension fund scandal a decade ago and have been blamed for being too restrictive on pension funds' investments.

More than a year ago the Department of Social Security asked the Institute of Actuaries set up a review of MFR, which requires pension funds to set up a certain amount of assets to cover payments to pensioners, including the idea of a central discontinuance fund which would operate in a similar way to an insurance fund.

But while the Institute of Actuaries presented its detailed analysis to social security ministers two months ago, it is yet to be published and be used as the basis for a wide-reaching consultation with the industry.

The MFR is said to force pension funds into buying too many government bonds, which in turn is distorting the price of the bonds. Alan Pickering, chairman of the National Association of Pension Funds which represents many of country's pension funds, said he found it a little frustrating that different government departments were sending out conflicting signals about the MFR.

Mr Pickering, who supports the idea of such a central discontinuance fund, said he wanted to see a "genuinely consultative paper" issued by the DSS and the Treasury. In addition to the actuarial report commissioned by the DSS, the Treasury's institutional investment review, headed by the Gartmore chairman Paul Myners is also considering its effect on investment behaviour.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: For What We Are About To Receive

fields.headline: For What We Are About To Receive
fields.standfirst:
Brunton Theatre, Musselburgh
*****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Brunton Theatre, Musselburgh
*****
fields.body:
One of a handful of impressive young female playwrights currently working in Scotland, Nicola McCartney has an almost forensic interest in family relations, and a rare skill in dramatically cutting to the heart of this universal matter. Sometimes, as in her play earlier this year, Home, her story-telling instincts are compromised by a too-stylised use of poetic language, jarring stuff that can undo the emotional pull of her narrative.

But not here, in a new play for the Brunton, a few miles outside of Edinburgh but well worth the journey. That forensic attention to the ties that bind us all takes centre stage in a powerful three-act play looking back over the life of one woman from the post-mortem table, in glimpses from the present day, the early 80s and 1951.

A small cast takes parts in each time frame - daughters become mothers, sons become fathers - underlining the play's fascination with fate and the way genetics and destiny might mix to make a life. This works well, drawing the audience into the puzzle of loose ends and clues that a pathologist throws out from the body of evidence before him - a baby an elderly woman doesn't want to talk about, a genetic defect we see the tragic results of long before we know the cause.

He does this from high up, towering above the players, scrubbed up in front of a blinding white backdrop. It's like the blank sheet we all start with, and the light at the end of the tunnel of life we're all chaotically heading for. Both of these - the blank beginning and the last light - and everything in between, McCartney dramatises with an emotional precision that will take your breath away.

Till August 26. Box office: 0131-665 2240.

fields.headline: Protesters hand over 'paedophile list'
fields.trailText: Protesters in Portsmouth have handed police a list of alleged paedophlies they want to be removed from a housing estate and called a halt to unofficial demonstrations.
fields.body:
Protesters in Portsmouth have handed police a list of alleged paedophiles they want to be removed from a housing estate and called a halt to unofficial demonstrations. Hampshire police have agreed to show the list of about 20 names to social services, and Portsmouth city council said it would give safe accommodation to any of those named who requested it..

Campaigners on the Paulsgrove estate met council and police officials this afternoon after suspending a week of violent protests in which small children marched next to their parents holding banners saying "Kill the paedophiles" and "Hang them".

Protesters agreed today not to stage any more demonstrations without police permission. They handed their list of names to the authorities at the weekend, police confirmed today. The list is believed to have been drawn up from information taken from the News of the World's Name and Shame campaign, material on the internet and nominations from people on the estate who claimed their children had been molested.

Police would not confirm the exact number of names on the list, or say how many are convicted paedophiles or how many have already been driven out.

A week-long series of violent protests, in which cars were burned and five families fled the estate, was suspended on Thursday after campaign leaders agreed to hand over their list of alleged paedophiles in a bid to have them removed from the estate.

Superintendent Bob Golding said that a total of 24 arrests had been made as a result of the violent protests on the estate. He said: "Names have been passed to us and there will be dialogue between us and the local authority." Not all of the names on the list were known sex offenders, he said.

Portsmouth city council's acting chief executive, Roger Ching, said: "Police are now studying that list and will share relevant information with the city council."

He said the council did not have the legal power to force people to move but would offer safe accommodation to those who felt they were at risk.

Mr Ching said he had agreed to set up a working group to help residents campaign for longer sentences for convicted paedophiles and to consider changes to the housing system. It had also been agreed that any future demonstrations on the estate would only be held after consultation between residents, the city council and the police.

The council had not capitulated to mob rule, said Mr Ching; it had come up with the best solution to help end the violent demonstrations. Residents could add more names to the list at any stage and a hotline number had been set up for anyone who felt children were at risk.

webTitle: How to put welfare cash on a new footing

fields.headline: How to put welfare cash on a new footing
fields.standfirst: Special report: road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Labour arrived in office with no clear strategy for the most expensive programme of all - the £100bn social security budget, which accounts for almost 30% of all government spending. Welfare reform became Labour's second dome, a goal to which they became committed without any clear idea of what they wanted.
fields.body:
Labour arrived in office with no clear strategy for the most expensive programme of all - the £100bn social security budget, which accounts for almost 30% of all government spending. Welfare reform became Labour's second dome, a goal to which they became committed without any clear idea of what they wanted.

Worse still, the national debate which ministers launched was conducted on the most fallacious of arguments: our welfare bills had become far too high (wrong, the UK was near to the bottom of the European league in the proportion of GDP spent on social protection); social security would have to be cut back to become sustainable (wrong, since as the government actually noted, we needed to spend only an extra 0.1% of GDP to sustain state pensions through to 2005, compared to a figure 30 times as high on the continent); welfare-to-work schemes would achieve savings which could be redirected to health and education (right policy, wrong analysis: there are few savings once job subsidies, training, childcare allowances and administrative costs are added.)

In the three years of opposition under Tony Blair, in which the only audacious aspect of their promises was their modesty, Labour made only one pledge, and that only in a newspaper interview, that was unequivocally progressive on reducing poverty: "If the next Labour government has not raised the living standards of the poorest by the end of its time in office, it will have failed."

After the worst of beginnings - sticking to Tory spending limits for two years, implementing the Tories' one parent benefit cut - the government is now on the road to creating a fairer society.

The first term goal will be achieved. Labour is on course to lift about 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty by April 2002. All families will have gained (by almost £850 a year) but poor families will have gained most of all (about £1,500). This is the biggest lift for poor children since the welfare state was launched in 1948, but there will still be more than twice as many children living in poverty at the end of this parliament as there were in 1979, last year of the last Labour government.

Labour already has an ambitious 20-year welfare goal, set out by the prime minister in a public address in 1999: "Our historic aim will be for ours to be the first generation to end child poverty. It is a 20-year mission," and a 10-year target was subsequently set by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of halving child poverty by 2009.

Child poverty (children living in households below half average income) increased threefold in the three decades up to 1997 - from 1.4m in 1968 to 4.4m in 1997, or one out of three of all children. This was the third worst rate of child poverty in the developed world.

The targets were also politically clever. Labour wanted to restore public support for the welfare system. What better client group to rally such support than children?

The chancellor has promised that his new integrated child credit, which will bring together the different strands of support for children except child benefit, will lift a further 1m children out of poverty when it is introduced in 2003. Excellent, but Labour should provide the figures and a date for the next million after that.

What should happen now?

Help for poorest: The most disadvantaged group in the first term has been people without work or children. These people - disabled, unemployed, chronically sick - have watched others being lifted up while their benefits have only been linked to prices.

Without an earnings link, a further 300,000 people in this group will fall below the poverty line. If Labour is to honour the second half of its manifesto mantra ("work for those who can, security for those who can't"), their benefits must be earnings linked. Indeed, given how far benefits have fallen below minimum living standards, the index should be 1% above earnings to help them begin to catch up.

Pensioners: The second poorest people are the elderly who only have the basic pension to live on. Labour has been right to concentrate its extra resources on these 500,000 people but should have made more determined efforts to find out who they are. Some 7m of the 10.8m pensioners are now drawing an occupational or personal pension. In a society in which 2% of pensioners now pay the top tax rate, it is wrong to make an across-the-board increase.

At present, poor single pensioners receive between £11 and £18.55 extra a week (according to age) through Labour's minimum income guarantee (MIG) on top of the £67.50 basic pension. Poor couples receive between £17.45 and £26.55 extra on top of the basic (£107.90). But since the Thatcher government cut the basic pension's link with earnings in 1981, single pensioners have lost £30 a week and couples £48. A radical government would restore this loss to the poorest pensioners by lifting MIG to the equivalent figure. This will create problems by lifting the poorest pensioners above pensioners who have some savings, but this could be solved by a pension credit so small savers are not penalised.

Social Fund: The fund was set up to provide grants to poor people needing cash for exceptional items - from pots and pans which wear out, to cookers that have to be replaced. People living on benefits have no savings to which they can turn in emergencies. An offer of a better but unfurnished flat can only be accepted if there is help with bedding and second-hand furniture. But in 1988 the Conservatives changed the rules, making the fund a predominantly loan issuing body - 1.8m loans compared to 225,000 grants in 1998/99. Labour condemned the move in 1988 and its national commission on social justice in 1994 described the fund as "perhaps the most soul-destroying aspect of income support". The grant system should be restored. It would cost less than 0.4% of the social security budget.

Sure Start: This is one of the most imaginative Labour schemes - offering support to parents of poor children through a variety of different schemes - but even after the expansion announced in the July comprehensive spending review, it only reaches one third of poor homes with children. Pre-school schemes in the US have shown that for every $1 invested, the state gets a return of $7. Labour should commit itself to offering such support to all poor households.

Universalism: Many Labour supporters still wish to replace means tests with a universal scheme. But private provision and ever widening income distribution, makes this unattainable.

Universal health and education schemes should be pursued, but on welfare, Labour should stick to its twin track: helping people back into work and boosting benefits for the poor.

Inequality: Labour has openly talked about the need to tackle poverty but still remains shy about the means needed to achieve such reform: redistribution. In its second term, it must be more open and include narrowing Britain's brutal inequalities in its social inclusion programme. Redistribution can be achieved not just through taxation but by adopting affluence tests, under which basic benefits get withdrawn when private benefits exceed a certain level.

Pledges

1. Link benefits of poorest - disabled, unemployed, chronically sick - to earnings

2. Restore earnings link for poorest pensioners - plus cash they've lost since 1981

3. Replace social fund loans with grants

4. Expand Sure Start scheme to all poor homes with children

5. Establish new strategy to reduce inequalities.

webTitle: John Sutherland on lousy university league tables

fields.headline: A contest that no one can really win
fields.standfirst:
John Sutherland on lousy league tables

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: John Sutherland on lousy university league tables
fields.body:
If you have friends who work in the university world, chances are they have been acting rather strangely over the last few months. Looking abstracted; muttering angrily to themselves; tearing out their hair. Another RAE - research assessment exercise - is coming up.

The scheme came into existence a decade ago. What happens is that every four years, each university department the length and breadth of Britain is required to list the scholarship it has produced since the last RAE. Every member of the department is expected to come up with four items - ideally four books if you're a humanist, four better mousetraps if you're a scientist. The lists have to be in by this December.

On the basis of the submission, an external panel grades the departments, creating gigantic sets of league tables out of the country's 110 or so universities. These are published next April, when the hair-tearing will begin again.

Grades run on a seven-point scale. A handful of winners get glory and research cash (what's called "R"). They will, over the next four years, have to raise less of their money from student enrolments (what's called "T", or teaching). Easy street for the top departments. Hard times, however, for the many losers. More classroom grind. And those colleagues who let the department down (no four books) may go to the wall.

The RAE was born out of the late Thatcher era, when some bright spark in Whitehall realised that competition and league tables were ways of getting quality without the pain of investing money (just as "naming and shaming" is a way of fighting crime without the expense of hiring more police).

With the RAE, you simply told the universities to slug it out like gladiators. Last one standing was the winner. And the effort to beat the opposition (or at least get a higher grade than last time) would, it was fondly thought, produce improvement. Competition is the law of the universe. Darwin taught us that.

It is a lousy system. Survival of the fittest may work for the animal kingdom, but it's bugger all use for tertiary education. Since the RAE was introduced, British universities have got a lot better at competing with each other, but have fallen behind in world competition - notably vis-à-vis their American counterparts.

It's analogous to Association Football. Britain has the most elaborate and fiercely competitive league system in the world. It takes the announcer a quarter of an hour to trawl through the results at five o'clock on Saturday. And yet we can't beat Portugal. The problem that faces British universities is not that they have become fat and lazy, but that they have been starved beyond lean efficiency into inanition.

Belatedly, the government has acknowledged the fact with one of its periodic (and pathetically inadequate) attempts to stanch the scientific brain drain. Four million pounds doesn't qualify as a finger in the dyke; you could find that much in the Dome petty-cash box.

Competition - like whipping a horse - undoubtedly stimulates performance. But if you don't feed the horse, you can whip all you like. You won't have a winner (although it may do well against other underfed nags).

There are worse effects of the RAE. It leads to a crudely quantitative view of research and "productivity". ("Do you have your four items?" colleagues will nervously ask one another - whether they're any good or not is a secondary consideration.) The war of all against all creates rivals out of natural allies. The scholars at neighbouring Birkbeck English department are not the opposition. But the RAE makes me think of them that way.

It skews appointments. Many departments, under intolerable pressure to raise their grade, go head-hunting for stars. What they don't want is the young scholar who won't have any listable piece of research for 10 years. Long-term investment in human resources? Forget it. We want our five-star next April. Appoint Professor Trendhound from the University of Cutting Edge - even if you have to break the bank to get him (oh, and by the way, he doesn't want to do any teaching and wants you to find a job for his partner).

Like the Ofsted inspections, RAE leads to human tragedies. Most departments will have colleagues who are intensely learned but for one reason or another don't write a lot. You can't cut learning into four listable items. Fire the bum - ah, Professor Trendhound, I do hope the red carpet was to your liking.

fields.headline: Jason Brown reveals how he ripped out 11 Sussex batsmen
fields.standfirst: Every week we go behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the best county performances of the last few days. Today we talk to Northamptonshire offspinner Jason Brown about his matchwinning efforts against Sussex at Wantage Road
fields.trailText: Jason Brown, 25, could be the answer to England's spin-bowling problems. After topping Northamptonshire's averages in 1998 with 33 wickets at 22.00, he played just once last season, after being troubled by a knee injury and then omitted in favour of left-arm spinner Michael Davies. But when Davies got the yips in June, Brown stepped in - and has been unstoppable since. In seven games he has picked up 50 wickets at 19.48 and is being widely tipped to tour West Indies with England A this winter. Last week he destroyed Sussex in the crucial top-of-the-second-division clash at the County Ground, Northampton, returning figures of 11-125, which included a career-best 7-78 in the second innings. Brown takes up the story
fields.body:
Jason Brown, 25, could be the answer to England's spin-bowling problems. After topping Northamptonshire's averages in 1998 with 33 wickets at 22.00, he played just once last season, after being troubled by a knee injury and then omitted in favour of left-arm spinner Michael Davies. But when Davies got the yips in June, Brown stepped in - and has been unstoppable since. In seven games he has picked up 50 wickets at 19.48 and is being widely tipped to tour West Indies with England A this winter. Last week he destroyed Sussex in the crucial top-of-the-second-division clash at the County Ground, Northampton, returning figures of 11-125, which included a career-best 7-78 in the second innings. Brown takes up the story

"The last few wickets we've played on at Northampton have turned more as the game went on. Our plan has been to bat first and rack up a big total. But this time we lost the toss and Sussex batted first. We kept them down to 232 and then Russell Warren got a big score [151].

"My first wicket was Robin Martin-Jenkins. It turned from wide outside off stump, didn't bounce much and went through the gate. Wasim Khan was next. I went round the wicket, the ball was angling down the legside and there was a little nick. It was pad first then bat and it went straight into Rollie's [Adrian Rollins] hands at short leg. [Umar] Rashid played on - he went back to cut and got a bottom edge onto his stumps, and [Jason] Lewry was caught at long-on by Darren [Cousins]. It was just a big yahoo really.

"Darren bowled well too [Cousins took 4-36, while Brown had figures of 32.3-12-53-4]. He's done well for us this season, and has got a lot of lbws because he bowls wicket to wicket.

"I try to give it a rip - I like to see it turn big, like to attack. I bowl into Paul Taylor's footmarks [Northamptonshire's veteran left-arm seamer] and let the rough do the rest. I was doing OK for the Second XI before I got picked this season. The wickets weren't taking much spin, but I was getting a few four-wicket hauls. [In the first team] the coach was going with the left-armer [Davies] and the offspinner [Graeme Swann]. I think we can fit all three in the same side - we all like to turn it. And me and Graeme have complemented each other well so far. We both put pressure on, and if one of us doesn't get wickets, then the other does [in tandem with Brown, Swann has taken 32 wickets at 25.88].

"In the second innings I got [Toby] Peirce first, caught behind. The ball turned and there was a faint nick. Then Chris Adams. It was a slower ball - it didn't bounce, but it turned and he played back to hit it through square-leg. It hit him just above the ankle - plumb! Martin-Jenkins was caught by Rollie under the helmet at short leg. It turned and bounced, he got a faint edge onto his pad and it looped up quite easily.

"Rashid was playing a few shots, so I gave him the slower ball, left it behind a bit. He played forward, it turned and took the outside edge, and it was another good catch for David Ripley. He's very good standing up behind the stumps. Toby Bailey [the No. 2 keeper] is good too, but Rips has the experience.

"For [Justin] Bates I bowled a quicker offspinner, quite straight and full. He went for the sweep and got a top edge to Graeme Swann in the 45-degrees position round the corner. Then I threw one up outside off to Jason Kirtley - it didn't bounce and hit him halfway up. Plumb again.

"Tony Cottey [112] played a fabulous innings. He used his feet, was quick to the ball and swept well. He didn't look in any trouble. He was in a different class - it was the first time I'd bowled to him. He kept trying to sweep me so I was going wider and wider of off stump. Eventually he tried to sweep one from really wide and dragged it onto his stumps.

"At the moment I'm trying not to look too far forward. It was hard enough getting into the Northants team, and there were times when I did think about leaving, even if it had meant starting in another county's second team. But I'm now in the second year of a three-year contract, and I'll still have to work hard. If an A-team spot comes up, then great. But at the moment Robert Croft's the best spinner in the country: that's why he's playing for England.

"My main wicket-taking delivery is probably my stock ball that pitches about a foot outside off. If it hits the rough, then it turns sharply and either keeps low or bounces. I used to watch Embers [John Emburey, who coached Northants from 1996-98] a lot, but I bowl with a bent front knee, which is unusual for spinners. I enjoyed watching Tim May bowl too: he liked to go wide of the crease, pitch it a foot outside off and make it turn big.

"My batting isn't really something I like talking about [laughs]. I don't get much of an opportunity really. I haven't had a net since the beginning of the season, so the only real practice I get is out in the middle. But I would like to improve my batting. If I don't get picked this winter, maybe I can work on it with David Capel, Nick Cook and Bob Carter [Northants' coach]. But I did bat all day recently for the seconds. I came in as nightwatchman against Warwickshire and saved the game with 39*.

"The boys are in good form at the moment. We're a close unit, we're enjoying it and there's plenty of good fun and banter in the training sessions. I think we can go on to win the second division."

Jason Brown was talking to Lawrence Booth. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Alan Mullally talks us through his 14-wicket haul for Hampshire against Derbyshire, click here

fields.headline: Woodhead attacks 'vacuous' degrees
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, yesterday accused universities of offering "vacuous" courses.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, yesterday accused universities of offering "vacuous" courses.

He claimed universities were devaluing higher education by offering a "plethora of quasi-academic" courses, citing examples such as media studies, knitwear, beauty therapy and golf course management.

Degrees such as media studies have enjoyed huge growth as universities have expanded the number of places to meet ambitious government targets. These courses have tended to originate from the polytechnics which were turned into universities in 1992.

In the Sunday Times, Mr Woodhead, who heads the office for standards in education, wrote: "What is the point of students completing a course only to find that their degree adds little or nothing to their employment prospects? Vocational qualifications will be valued only when they are attractive to students and employers alike and when they lead to worthwhile employment.

"This simple truth has eluded politicians, who have sacrificied the integrity of vocational training on the altar of vacuous theoretial convolution."

Mr Woodhead's comments came as thousands of sixth-formers await the results of their A-levels exams this Thursday.

Mr Woodhead, a cynic about vocational training, added: "We spend £6bn a year on higher education. We need to be certain that undergraduate study is in the interests of the individuals."

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment said: "Degrees are developed and offered by universities, not the government. The universities operate in a market and where there is no demand, courses will not be run and will not be funded."

Figures published today by the universities and colleges admissions service show that the proportion of students from relatively poor families has barely increased over the last six years.

fields.headline: Grasping the nettle of reform
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, a former Whitehall manderin, gives a reality check to the Guardian's proposals for constitutional change
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Kemp, a former Whitehall manderin, gives a reality check to the Guardian's proposals for constitutional change.
fields.body:
The manifesto should accept that while a good deal has been done on constitutional matters in the first term, much remains to do.

The argument that these matters are uninteresting to the electorate, as against say health or education may be true. But there is still real work to do - and anyway the one should not exclude the other. Thus:

&149; The position on devolution isn't stable. More needs to be devolved including hitherto largely untouched areas such as tax and social security

&149; More hard thinking is needed about the English regions and their role alongside strengthened local authorities

&149; House of Lords reform is at half cock. To give it real legitimacy, the manifesto should promise a fully-elected second chamber, risking the perverse effects of the party system.

&149; The nettle of proportional representation for the Commons should be grasped. A referendum, certainly - but the manifesto should indicate the government's view. That is not easy to do objectively in the run-up to an election being fought - and very likely won - under the present system.

For judges, the advent of the Human Rights Act makes the case for independent appointment even stronger. At the very least, an "advise and consent" process is needed, in the hands of a Commons committee, which must itself operate under strengthened Commons independence which should be promised.

The question of the monarchy is blazingly sensitive. But for the manifesto to propose a legitimisation and facilitation of the debate already under way, looking broadly and - for now - timelessly at the issues that arise, would probably be acceptable to many people who recognise that the debate is not to go away.

Reform of the senior civil service and the departmental and central Whitehall structure is another area where the steps the government has taken so far are at best half-baked and at worst backward looking.

Departments of a kind need to remain, but newly-configured and made more appropriate and versatile to meet the cross border issues that arise. Sir Humphrey should go - genuinely - and be replaced by good (non-spinning) policy advisers and departmental chief executives. These people must be professionally and technically skilled and be able work with the heads of agencies and departments experienced and competent in the actual delivery of policy.

webTitle: Search widened as fears for missing boy grow

fields.headline: Search widened as fears for missing boy grow
fields.standfirst: Graphic: Brancaster bay
fields.trailText: Hopes are fading that a five-year-old boy, who vanished yesterday during a day trip to a Norfolk beach, will be found alive.
fields.body:
Hopes are fading that a five-year-old boy, who vanished yesterday during a day trip to a Norfolk beach, will be found alive.

The search for Jake Parker widened at dawn, with three lifeboats, divers and a shore patrol scanning the coastline around Brancaster beach in north Norfolk. However Peter Furlong, coastguard sector manager for north Norfolk, said: "The chances of a little boy surviving in the water for all this time are negligible.

"An experienced sailor properly kitted-out with a lifejacket may be able to survive in these waters for a night. This little boy was wearing shorts and a T-shirt."

Jake, who disappeared at lunchtime yesterday, was last seen paddling at the water's edge. A relative who was looking after the youngster lost sight of him "for just a few seconds" before realising he was gone.

The youngster was playing in the water at low tide, about half a mile from sand dunes at the top of the beach.

Coastguards said that shortly after he disappeared, a 12-year-old girl had told her parents that she thought she had seen a little boy's body in the water.

Jake's parents, Kevin and Debbie, from Wellingborough, Northants, are said to be distraught. They and his 10-year-old sister are being cared for by police.

A huge search operation was mounted yesterday, swelled by local volunteers and golfers from the nearby Royal West Norfolk golf club at Brancaster. Today two lifeboats from Hunstanton and one from Wells-next-the-Sea put out at first light, accompanied by teams searching the shore inch by inch.

Police are treating the incident as a missing person case, however chief inspector Sandra Wilkinson said: "The main thrust of our investigation has to be that he was swept away."

Tides along the stretch of the Norfolk coast near Hunstanton are notoriously fast-moving, with channels, gullies and sandbars posing added dangers. The shelving off the Norfolk coast and the undulating nature of some beaches creates strong currents which make certain parts of the sea very difficult to swim in.

Almost exactly four years ago, two children drowned after being swept out to sea from a beach just five miles from Brancaster. Six-year-old Jodi Loughlin and her brother Tom, four, were missing for two weeks after disappearing from the beach at Holme-next-the-Sea. Their bodies were later washed up along the coast.

Gareth May, a Hunstanton beach lifeguard, said there would probably be discussions about whether a lifeguard should be permanently based on Old Hunstanton beach in the future.

Only beaches in towns with large populations along the Norfolk coast have lifeguard stations. The lifeguards are paid for by local councils, which have previously argued that it is impractical to station lifeguards on every isolated beach along the coast.

Today two lifeboats from Hunstanton and one from Wells-next-the-Sea put out at first light, accompanied by teams searching the shore inch by inch. Police are treating the incident as a missing person case, however chief inspector Sandra Wilkinson said: "The main thrust of our investigation has to be that he was swept away." Tides along the stretch of the Norfolk coast near Hunstanton are notoriously fast-moving, with channels, gullies and sandbars posing added dangers. The shelving off the Norfolk coast and the undulating nature of some beaches creates strong currents which make certain parts of the sea very difficult to swim in. Almost exactly four years ago, two children drowned after being swept out to sea from a beach just five miles from Brancaster. Six-year-old Jodi Loughlin and her brother Tom, four, were missing for two weeks after disappearing from the beach at Holme-next-the-Sea. Their bodies were later washed up along the coast. Gareth May, a Hunstanton beach lifeguard, said there would probably be discussions about whether a lifeguard should be permanently based on Old Hunstanton beach in the future. Only beaches in towns with large populations along the Norfolk coast have lifeguard stations. The lifeguards are paid for by local councils, which have previously argued that it is impractical to station lifeguards on every isolated beach along the coast.
