Deutsche Telekom was initially considered a competitor to Orange in bidding for Sonera. However, Deutsche Telekom's recent acquisition of VoiceStream now makes this unlikely. Dutch KPN Telecom is another possible rival. Orange may use equity to achieve a takeover of Sonera. Britain's third biggest mobile group, bought by France Télécom earlier this year, is planning to list by December. Orange sources said a $30bn (£20bn) offer, which would value Sonera at around $41 a share, was a little high. A Sonera spokesman declined to confirm the speculation yesterday. The Finnish government gained parliamentary approval to reduce its stake in Sonera to zero, which could be achieved either through share-based mergers and acquisitions, sales or other strategic investments. Orange, Sonera and Spain's Telefonica were partners in the race to win a third generation (3G) mobile phone licence in Germany. However, the takeover by France Télécom meant Orange had to withdraw from the 3G contest to avoid a conflict of interest. France Telecom was also bidding in the German auction. Sonera would fit with Orange and France Télécom's strategy to build a global wireless business to rival that of Vodafone. Orange and Sonera are considered similar as both companies are at the forefront of technological developments in data services on mobiles as well as bill paying systems. The string of multi-billion mobile phone deals are becoming commonplace as each of the operators jostle to gain scale. As a small but successful operator Sonera is well aware of the challenges it faces with a tiny subscriber base, despite operating in the market that has the world's highest penetration of mobile usage. Sonera also owns a 37.3% stake in Turkcell and is building networks in Hungary and the Baltics. It also owns a string of valuable minority holdings in VoiceStream, Powertel and Eliska Wireless Ventures. Sonera has developed one of the most advanced wireless internet portals, called Zed, and a software encryption system, SmartTrust, to allow secure shopping from mobiles. Commerzbank said in a report recently that a takeover of Sonera would be done best if Sonera's management could retain the high level of independence that Hans Snook achieved when Orange was sold to France Télécom. A deal depends on how much the Finnish government is prepared to sacrifice as Sonera is the country's second largest listed company. In the middle of this year Finland's communications minister Olli-Pekka Heinonen, said the government did not want "Sonera to become a bite-sized morsel for someone else to swallow".  Telefonica said yesterday it was determined to win a 3G mobile phone licence in Germany, despite being seen as an outsider likely to drop out of the race. "In Germany we are very serious and we have more steam and financial means than others," said a Telefonica Moviles spokesman. After Debitel abandoned its bid on Friday after the price for a licence climbed well past 10 billion marks (£3bn).

fields.headline: Loretta Young
fields.standfirst:
From silents to television shows: Hollywood's durable glamour girl

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: At the Academy Award ceremony of 1947, it seemed a foregone conclusion that Rosalind Russell would win the Oscar for best actress, for Mourning Becomes Electra. But when the envelope was opened, out came the name of Loretta Young. There was a gasp from the audience.
fields.body:
At the Academy Award ceremony of 1947, it seemed a foregone conclusion that Rosalind Russell would win the Oscar for best actress, for Mourning Becomes Electra. But when the envelope was opened, out came the name of Loretta Young. There was a gasp from the audience.

Nobody was more surprised than Young, then aged 35, as she made her way up to the stage. All she could say, on receiving the Oscar for her part in The Farmer's Daughter, was "At long last", an understandable comment from a woman who had been in the business so long: she made her first screen appearance at the age of four.

Young, who has died aged 87, was born in Salt Lake City, Utah, and was three when her parents separated and her mother moved with her five children to Hollywood, where she opened a boarding house. A year later, the child appeared in The Only Way (1917), paid $3.50 a day for playing a patient weeping on the operating table. At eight, she and her siblings were Arab children in the Rudolph Valentino film, The Sheik (1921). Her three sisters had acting ambitions too; one became the actress Sally Blane.

At 14, while at convent school, Young returned to the screen in a supporting role in Naughty But Nice (1927). She got the part by default. Director Mervyn LeRoy wanted one of her sisters, but Young asked if she might do. This led to a contract with First National, and a change of name. The studio thought her real name, Gretchen, "sounded too Dutchy", and changed it to Loretta, the favourite saint of the star of the film, Coleen Moore.

Young often took herself for her saintly namesake, irritating her colleagues. While working on The Stranger (1945), there was a scene where she was supposed to walk off with Orson Welles instead of attending Sunday morning mass. But as a devout Catholic, she refused to be shown on screen dodging church. Reluctantly, Wells changed it to another day of the week. She always objected to casts and crews swearing, and would set up a "swear box", giving the fines to Catholic charities.

But saint she was not. She was married three times and divorced twice, and had affairs with, among others, George Brent, Clark Gable (said to be the father of her "adopted" daughter), David Niven, Joseph Mankiewicz, William Wellman and Spencer Tracy. Wellman and the married Tracy came to blows over her. Young and Tracy had played down-and-outs sharing a shanty in Frank Borzage's Man's Castle (1933). Though it pre-dated the Hays Code, it was censored because of the character's out-of-wedlock pregnancy. Of their off-screen romance, Young remarked, "Since Spence and I were both Catholic, and can never be married, we have agreed not to see each other any more."

In 1930, she had eloped with co-star Grant Withers in imitation of the plot of the film Too Young To Marry. The marriage was annulled the following year, with Withers describing Young as "a steel butterfly".

She was determinedly litigious. In 1966, she sued NBC for $2.5m when they used the introductions to her old TV shows, because the 1950s fashions dated her; she sued them again in 1972, and won $600,000 for their unlawful exhibition of her TV shows abroad. In 1969, she sued 20th Century-Fox for $54,000 because the movie Myra Breckinridge contained clips from her films, used without her permission. The studio cut them out.

Thirty years before, Young had left Fox, which had labelled her too difficult; then she found that few studios would meet her price of $150,000 a picture, and was advised to lower it. When Columbia mogul Harry Cohn refused to pay $300 for a dress she had bought for her role in Bedtime Story (1942), she made herself available only for night-time fittings, adding to the budget.

According to Robert Preston, her co-star in The Lady From Cheyenne, "she worked with a full-length mirror beside the camera. I didn't know which Loretta to play to - the one in the mirror or the one that was with me." Virginia Field, with whom she worked on Eternally Yours, commented, "She was and is the only actress I really dislike. She was sickeningly sweet, a pure phony. Her two faces sent me home angry and crying."

But Young was physically exquisite, and had a genuine touch of class. She started as a Hollywood leading lady in Laugh Clown, Laugh (1928), playing a tightrope walker. The director Herbert Brenon, who had tested 48 other girls for the role, told Loretta, 15: "Your legs can be padded. Likewise your body. It's your eyes that are getting you the part."

She remembered that "my first director taught me not to take myself seriously, but to take my work seriously, never to be satisfied unless I was doing my very best." She first did her best in minor melodramas and comedies. After acting a miscast Jean Harlow off the screen in Frank Capra's Platinum Blonde (1931) at Columbia, she was given meatier parts at Warner Bros in Taxi and The Hatchet Man.

When she moved to Fox in 1934, the head of the studio, Darryl F Zanuck decided she was ideal for period pieces. She played Robert Clive's wife in Clive Of India (1935) and the Empress Eugenie in Suez (1938). She was touching as the deaf girl in The Story of Alexander Graham Bell (1938), in which her sisters also had parts.

The Farmer's Daughter was originally intended for Ingrid Bergman. In a blonde wig and Swedish accent, Young was convincing as a headstrong farm girl whose homespun ideas earn her a seat in Congress in a contest against the man she loves. This was followed by the title roles in the comedy The Bishop's Wife (1947) and as the 1820 bondswoman in Rachel And The Stranger (1948).

Her career petered out in the early 1950s, to be revived by her long-running TV show. Each 30-minute drama was introduced by the star. "After the audience has seen me well groomed, I can wear horrible clothes and ugly makeup or even a false nose, without anyone wondering whether I've aged overnight."

After her divorce in 1968 from producer/writer Thomas Lewis, with whom she had two children, Young wrote a syndicated lonely-hearts column in Catholic newspapers, and worked as a consultant for the wedding dress firm, Brides Showcase International. At 81 she married costume designer Jean Louis (he did her famous TV show frocks), who died three years ago.

She devoted herself to Catholic charities in the 1980s, selling her Hollywood home and jewels to finance her work. "They are the luxuries of life ... If selling a bracelet will help feed children, that is what I want to do," she explained. She might have been making some progress at last towards her canonisation.

 Loretta (Gretchen Michaela) Young, actress, born January 6, 1913; died August 12 2000

fields.headline: Football hooligans raise their game
fields.standfirst:
Violence is being stepped up and becoming more coordinated, according to intelligence report that will embarrass the authorities
Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: Large scale football violence is becoming increasingly common with hooligans using the internet and mobile phones to arrange confrontations.
fields.body:
Large scale football violence is becoming increasingly common with hooligans using the internet and mobile phones to arrange confrontations.

Figures released by the national criminal intelligence service, show that violence is again marring the domestic game, much of it taking place away from grounds or after matches have finished.

The figures will embarrass government and football officals who have insisted that hooliganism usually takes place abroad when the national team is playing.

While the overall number of arrests for hooliganism fell slightly to 3,137 last season, from 3,341 in the season 1998-1999, attacks were more violent and better organised, often involving weapons.

Last season, there were 83 particularly violent incidents. In one of the most serious confrontations Stoke City and Cardiff City supporters battled throughout the day and into the night when the two teams met in a second division match. Other organised confrontations involved supporters of Wolverhampton Wanderers, Chelsea, Sunderland and Manchester City.

There were a number of mass arrests with dozens of hooligans being rounded up to prevent trouble. In one incident, 168 Chelsea fans were arrested as they planned to attack Tottenham Hotspur fans.

The number of arrests for racist chanting also increased with 34 people arrested compared to 25 during the 1998-99 season. Missile throwing also made an unwelcome return with 88 fans arrested for the offence last season compared to 42 the season before.

Sunderland top the arrest league with 223 arrests last season followed by Chelsea, with 168 arrests. Macclesfield and Wycombe Wanderers had no arrests at their grounds while Manchester United had 88 arrests from a total crowd of 1.04m who attended their matches last season.

There were 1,461 arrests in the Premiership, 831 in division one, 586 in division two and 259 in division three.

With CCTV cameras installed at all league grounds and many matches heavily policed, the criminal intelligence service said most violence now takes place away from stadiums, particularly in town centres or as fans are travelling to or away from matches.

The stereotype of the hooligan is changing, with many from middle class backgrounds working in the professions. The organisers are also involved in other criminal activity such as drug dealing and theft and are using technology to arrange confrontations. Bryan Drew, head of strategic and specialist intelligence at NCIS said: "Football hooliganism is more sophisticated than it was.

"Invariably, the incidents are away from grounds and are therefore more difficult to police. The criminal hooligan element often know when a game is going to be 'police free' and far from being mindless they are often organised and adept at exploiting spontaneous situations."

With the English football season starting last Saturday and the Premiership begining this weekend, police and football officals are hoping that the Football Spectators Act which comes into force next month will curb hooliganism.

The law will prevent known hooligans from attending matches, either in Britain or abroad, and police will have the power to detain those they suspect of planning violence.

The Home Office minister Lord Bassam said on Radio 4's The World this Weekend: "Ten years ago we had something like 10,000 arrests (for football hooliganism) annually. Now that is down to around 3,000. We should not be complacent. There was a big problem at Euro 2000 and we have taken measures to stop it.

"The overall total number of arrests maybe down but the hooligans are still with us and there is clearly a hard core of thugs trying to have weekly pre-organised fights some way from the stadium."

A spokesman for the Football Association said: "They are not football supporters, they are criminals."

Trouble spots for fans

Cardiff City v Millwall, August 9, 1999, Nationwide League Div 2 and return fixture December 12

At Cardiff, a six-year-old girl received head injuries after being hit by a missile after clashes between 500 home fans and Millwall supporters.

The return fixture saw trouble all day. At the game's end 90 seats were ripped up and thrown on to the pitch by Cardiff fans.

Arsenal v Manchester United, August 22, Premiership

At Holloway Road underground station 10 Arsenal supporters looking for opposing fans attacked a man on a train leaving him unconscious.

England v Argentina, February 22, international

Ten Derby fans attacked drinkers in a pub popular with Spurs fans. The Derby fans were chased out and received serious injuries. One nearly had an arm severed.

Birmingham City v Wolverhampton Wanderers, April 1, Nationwide League Div 1

A petrol bomb was thrown as 100 fans clashed with bottles, pool cues and bricks, leaving two men seriously injured.

Bristol Rovers v Stoke City, April 1, Nationwide League Div 2

The Stoke goalkeeper was attacked in quick succession by two Bristol fans.

Leicester City v Everton, April 8, Premiership

After this fixture a group of Muslims who were distributing leaflets in the city centre were attacked. One sustained a broken jaw. Their attackers were identified as Leicester City supporters.

Stoke City v Cardiff City, April 4, Nationwide League Div 2

A group of around 300 Cardiff supporters under police escort to the stadium were repeatedly ambushed by a group of around 600-800 Stoke supporters. Searches of fans yielded a circular saw and 100 Stanley knives.

Rotherham v Swansea, May 6, Nationwide League Div 3

This was a high profile fixture with the championship to be decided. During disturbances a Swansea supporter sustained fatal injuries.

 Source: NCIS

fields.headline: Anarchists flaunt counter-culture
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The banner spells out the theme of the gathering: "Whoever they vote for, we are ungovernable".
fields.body:
The banner spells out the theme of the gathering: "Whoever they vote for, we are ungovernable".

While the Democrats assemble downtown for the razzmatazz coronation of Al Gore and the Reform party disperses in chaos in Long Beach, the North American Anarchist Conference has been meeting quietly at the weekend in a crowded studio just north of Dodger Stadium, the home of one of Los Angeles's baseball teams.

For the coming week Los Angeles will be the focal point of US protest, and the American anarchists have a tradition of involvement in such battles, stretching back to the beginning of the last century.

This has made them suspicious of the police and the media, and many of those on the door at the studio building have obscured their faces with Zapatista-style bandanas and wear badges naming them as Idiot, Corpse, Sativa or Stream.

There are many young activists in black T-shirts with badges honouring everything from the anarchist band, Crass, to the Industrial Workers of the World, better known as the Wobblies.

Cameras and tape-recorders are banned, and everywhere notices warn of the possibility of police infiltrators or raids. No drugs, alcohol or weapons are permitted. "Nothing that will endanger the safety and security of others" is allowed.

The first discussion of the day is not on plans for this week's street protests but on Liberation Pedagogy, including suggestions that children should be encouraged not to go to school until the system has changed. But the 500 or so anarchists assembled here, split fairly equally between the sexes, are aware that the media are focused mainly on the part their members will play in the street protests.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Arriva, the buses and car dealership group, is being stalked by a private equity group and could be the subject of a takeover bid. Both Arriva and Go-Ahead could be taken over this year, according to analysts.

Abbey National and Alliance & Leicester are expected to face increasing pressure from shareholders to put themselves up for sale following Barclays' takeover of Woolwich, according to the Observer. The newspaper did not name its source, but said Abbey is rumoured to have held talks with a number of potential suitors, including Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, but chief executive Ian Harley appears to be determined to retain his independence.

Sunday Business

ONdigital, the digital terrestial broadcaster owned by ITV companies Carlton and Granada, is to float on the stock market within six months with a price tag of about £2bn. Isabel Maxwell, eldest daughter of disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, is to enter the British business world by joining the board of internet start up Espotting.com.

Online auctioneer QXL is pondering a substantial cut in its offer for the German online auction house Ricardo.de. The all-share bid was originally worth £670m, but it is now valued at £230m and is expected to be marked down further.

Sunday Times

Sir Martin Laing, chairman of Nursing Home Properties, Britain's biggest nursing home group, is to hold a crisis meeting with chief executive, Richard Ellert, this week after the collapse in the share price.

Fund managers want more aggressive performance-related pay for company directors, bringing Britain into line with the US where the most successful executives can have salary packages worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

Royal & Sun Alliance is planning a New York stock exchange flotation this autumn. Sources say the company is believed to be in discussions with US regulators about the details and timing of the listing, due at the end of October.

Sunday Telegraph

Telesens, the German software services group, is poised to acquire KSCL, the Scottish software company owned by Kingston Communications, the Hull telecoms group, 3i and Royal Bank Development Capital, for up to £300m.

Singer & Friedlander has made a takeover approach to BWD Securities in an effort to transform itself into a pure investment management group. Bankers believe Singer & Friedlander is likely to have to pay at least £160m to buy the business. Merrill Lynch is thought also to be in talks to buy the business for up to £300m.

GKN, the engineering and aerospace group, has put Westland Heliport up for sale offering the buyer a chance to own central London's only helicopter landing site

ITM Activate, the media company which has the rights to operate the National Union of Students' internet business, is to float for up to £1bn next spring in a move which should provide the student organisation with a welcome windfall worth up to £50m.

Abbey National is working on plans to hand over the running of its credit card, general insurance and mortgage processing operations in an attempt to cut costs by more than £150m a year.

Mail on Sunday

Only two of the scores of creditors of Boo.com, crashed internet retailer, will receive any of the £30m they are owed by the company. NatWest Bank's Lombard Finance and GE Capital had claims over computers used and are likely to get some money back. Boo's 250 former employees get £800 each.

Sunday Express

Actress Melanie Griffith has told friends that she expects to make $100m from an internet business she co-founded. However executives were unable to explain how she arrived at her lofty projections.

IoS

Partners in Andersen Consulting could receive shares worth $10m (£6.7m) each if the firm decides to float after winning its freedom from sister company Arthur Andersen.

Sir Stanley Kalms
In a report on Saturday, we said that Sir Stanley Kalms had seen his annual pay increase by £40,000. In fact Sir Stanley, the chairman of Dixons, took home £768,000 - £41,000 less than last year. Our apologies.

Today

Interims WH Ireland Group, Lavendon Group, Medical Solutions, Millenium & Copthorne, Sherwood International, WPP, Xenova. Finals NWF Group. AGMs Drummond Group. EGMs None Scheduled.

Tuesday

Interims ASDA, Biotrace International, Headlam Group, Independent Insurance Group, Mersey Docks & Harbour Co, Pifco Holdings, Proudfoot Consulting, Sanderson Bramall Motor Group . Finals Stoves Group. AGMs Castings, John Swan & Sons. EGMs None Scheduled.

Wednesday

Interims Balfour Beatty, JSB Software Technologies (Q4), Morgan Sindall, patsystems, Reckitt & Benckiser (Q2), Weir Group. Finals None Scheduled. AGMs AIM Distribution, Universal Salvage. EGMs Era Group, Henderson High Income.

Thursday

Interims Cordiant, Green Property, P&O Nedlloyd, Quantica. Finals Future Integrated Telephony. AGMs None scheduled. EGMs Advanced Technology (UK).

Friday

Interims NSB Retail Systems. Finals T Clarke. AGMs None scheduled. EGMs None scheduled.

Indicators this week
Today

UK CBI quarterly SME survey. UK PPI (July). US Business inventories (June). Japan Industrial output revision (June).

Tuesday

UK CPI (July). UK EEF pay settlements report. US Industrial production, (capacity in use, July).

Wednesday

Thursday

fields.headline: Rocket man plans solo flight
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Steve Bennett shook a sheaf of yellow ignition wires out of a bag on to a pitted wooden lab bench. They cost about a pound each. In less than 18 months, he will literally bet his life that DIY warehouse components like this can do what only government billions have done before: send a man - namely, himself - shooting skywards in a multi-stage rocket.
fields.body:
Steve Bennett shook a sheaf of yellow ignition wires out of a bag on to a pitted wooden lab bench. They cost about a pound each. In less than 18 months, he will literally bet his life that DIY warehouse components like this can do what only government billions have done before: send a man - namely, himself - shooting skywards in a multi-stage rocket.

For Nasa's vast Cape Canaveral assembly halls, downsize to a crowded workshop at Salford University. For the steppes of Baikonour, substitute the sands of Morecambe Bay at low tide. And for Yuri Gagarin and Wernher von Braun rolled into one, accept, if you will, Mr Bennett.

The would-be pioneer rocket pilot has a burning conviction that rocket science is ... well, not rocket science. In November next year he plans to prove it with his Nova rocket, which will fly to 10,000ft in 30 seconds with him squeezed into a capsule on top, before returning launch vehicle, capsule, and hopefully him to earth for reuse. All this for a mere £250,000.

"A lot of what we use we can actually pick up at B&Q," said Mr Bennett, 37. "The nuts and bolts don't have to be aerospace grade."

Mr Bennett prides himself in the uncomplicated, tried and trusted bits and pieces which will make up Britain's first manned rocket, the design of which is seen here for the first time.

Despite university backing, despite modest sponsorship from firms like Microsoft, despite 10 out of 12 of his unmanned rocket launches going as planned, the reputation of an unhinged amateur boffin clings to Mr Bennett - "the Eddie the Eagle of rockets", as he says resentfully.

There is something of a Wallace and Gromit atmosphere in the workshop. Apart from a mock-up of a space capsule for a future, three-person rocket, and various smaller nose cones and sections of fuselage, the most visible apparatus is a fridge and a kettle. "That's how I keep the team going. Free tea, free biscuits," he said.

Then he fetches a small cardboard box from a store cupboard and brings out something about the size of a toilet roll.

It is solid rocket fuel,as used in Nasa's space shuttle, imported from Nevada for £100 a slug. It's a reminder that, far out as he seems, Mr Bennett is the only enterpreneur in Europe to be making real rockets, like the two stage Starchaser-Discovery which roared into the north-western skies in July.

It is thanks to Mr Bennett that British amateur rocketeers can legally import the fuel, classed as an explosive. And it is due to him that the government is being forced to change the law, which now allows anyone, in theory, to fire rockets into the skies over Britain any time.

Mr Bennett now directs his efforts towards cadging sponsorship and free materials, persuading experts to give their time, and rallying a band of helpers.

Nova is an intermediate step toward realising Mr Bennett's dream of winning the $10m X Prize, offered by a group of Americans to the first non-government organisation which can take three people 100 km - 62 miles - above the earth, bring them back safely, and reuse the spacecraft no more than two weeks later.

The plan is for Nova to be launched on an unmanned test flight next summer before Mr Bennett straps himself in. If Nova succeeds, his company, Starchaser Industries, will go on to build its X Prize rocket, to be named Thunderbird after the sci-fi puppet series which fired Mr Bennett's imagination as a child.

At 12, he opened an account with a laboratory supplies company and began launching miniature rockets from behind his family's council house in Dukinfield, Greater Manchester.

After various jobs, including a spell in the army, he settled down as a soap and toothpaste analyst at Colgate Palmolive. Some of the time at Colgate was spent manufacturing rocket fuel out of sugar on the sly."I guess as a kid I was a closet pyromaniac," he said. "My favourite time of year was bonfire night. The alchemists and wizards, they summoned up demonic forces and made them do their bidding. That's just what rocketry is all about."

fields.headline: Cheney gets $20m oil job pay-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Republican presidential candidate George W Bush said yesterday that he saw nothing improper in the weekend revelation that his running mate Dick Cheney has been given a "retirement" package worth $20m by the Texas oil multinational at which he has worked for less than five years.
fields.body:
The Republican presidential candidate George W Bush said yesterday that he saw nothing improper in the weekend revelation that his running mate Dick Cheney has been given a "retirement" package worth $20m by the Texas oil multinational at which he has worked for less than five years.

The payment was agreed by the Dallas-based Halliburton Corporation on July 26, the same day that Mr Bush announced he had selected Mr Cheney. Had he resigned, clauses in his contract could have forced him to forfeit $10m or more in stock options and compensation.

The news of Mr Cheney's latest windfall comes as details of the extent of the former US defence secretary's personal wealth from the oil business continued to emerge. It drew angry attacks from the Democrats.

"They'll turn the Oval Office into the Oil Office", Al Gore's spokesman, Chris Lehane, said yesterday, adding that the question was whether Mr Cheney's ties would affect US energy and foreign policy under a Republican administration.

Mr Bush told the Los Angeles Times in an interview that he saw no reason for Mr Cheney, 59, to stay out of energy-related policy deliberations because of his ties to the industry.

But he added: "What I want him to do is not be owning oil stocks so he benefits from decisions we make in the administration. He'll follow the same rules I'll follow and that is we'll put all of our assets into blind trusts."

Like Mr Bush, Mr Cheney has amassed great personal wealth from the oil industry. His salary at Halliburton, which he joined in 1995, was $2m a year, but he also owns or has options on more than 1m Halliburton shares, worth $51m at current market prices. In May, Mr Cheney sold 100,000 shares, at a $5m profit.

Mr Cheney has made clear that he has no intention of selling his other shares unless he is elected in November. "Why not? I'm not on the government roll yet, I have no control over policy," he said last Friday.

Mr Cheney is also entitled to $2.1m in "deferred compensation", which earns 10% interest while it goes unclaimed.

"The American public should be pleased that they have a vice-presidential nominee who has been successful," Mr Bush's spokeswoman Karen Hughes said yesterday.

fields.headline: Markets wary of Japanese interest
fields.trailText: So far so good. Japan abandoned its zero interest rate policy on Friday and raised the cost of borrowing for the first time in 10 years. The markets took the announcement in their stride.
fields.body:
So far so good. Japan abandoned its zero interest rate policy on Friday and raised the cost of borrowing for the first time in 10 years. The markets took the announcement in their stride.

The move came too late in the day to have much impact in the far east, but in Europe and the US it prompted little reaction. By the end of trading in London, the yen, which some thought would strengthen, was unchanged at 108.7 to the dollar.

Masaru Hayami, the Bank of Japan's governor, will no doubt have felt vindicated. Yet, the longer they think about it, the more the markets might begin to doubt the wisdom of his action.

Despite a mild recovery of company profitability and a pick up in investment spending, largely due to the buoyancy of global demand, the domestic economy remains weak and consumer prices are still falling. Few independent analysts share Mr Hayami's belief "that the economy has reached the stage where deflationary concern has been dispelled".

At the same time that the economy's cyclical position is in doubt, a programme of structural reform is under way which, while ultimately beneficial, could depress demand in the short term. The collapse last month of the Sogo department store group, Japan's largest non- financial bankruptcy, shows that banks and corporations are at last beginning to wake up to to the reality of rising loan-losses and bad assets.

Instead of focusing on providing lifetime employment, firms are putting profitability first. In the long run, this should ensure their survival, but the dole queue is likely to lengthen and nervous consumers could become even more wary of spending.

Mr Hayami's determination to increase interest rates - he has been agitating to do so since April - was intended to spur the reform process by taking away the crutch of free money. But the danger is that the economy will fall over. In a report published on Friday, the IMF said that reform was best carried out against a backdrop of a recovery and that today's upswing remained "fragile and subject to downside risk".

The early removal of a stimulatory monetary policy could send the economy back into recession, it warned.

In 1997, the Japanese government tightened fiscal policy prematurely. It subsequently spent far more in stimulatory fiscal packages than the savings it originally planned to make.

The markets will be watching the Japanese economic data due out over the next few weeks with a keener interest than usual in order to judge whether Mr Hayami has made a similar mistake over monetary policy.

The markets will be watching the Japanese economic data due out over the next few weeks with a keener interest than usual in order to judge whether Mr Hayami has made a similar mistake over monetary policy.

fields.headline: Filling up regardless
fields.standfirst:
Dump the Pump is a damp squib - but that is because ever-increasing fuel taxes do not have the effect that they are supposed to have
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Drivers are today being urged to boycott BP service stations as part of the campaign to persuade Gordon Brown to cut the cost of motoring. So far, Dump the Pump has been a damp squib. The RAC, while sympathising with motorists, believes there are better ways of getting the message across.
fields.body:
Drivers are today being urged to boycott BP service stations as part of the campaign to persuade Gordon Brown to cut the cost of motoring. So far, Dump the Pump has been a damp squib. The RAC, while sympathising with motorists, believes there are better ways of getting the message across.

Whatever its final outcome, however, the brouhaha about the cost of motoring raises big questions about the UK tax system. Has the government's willingness to push up excise duties faster than the rate of inflation merely accentuated the trend started by Margaret Thatcher of making taxes less progressive - that is, landing the poor with a larger tax bill? And is there any evidence that raising excise duties can be used to curb consumption of things the government doesn't like, such as pollution and deaths related to tobacco?

Despite the changes of the past 20 years, the tax system is still progressive because people pay more tax as they get richer. But, as the Institute for Fiscal Studies notes, "the switch from direct to indirect taxes has reduced the progressivity of the tax system to the advantage of those on high incomes and at the expense of those on low incomes".

What has happened is that governments have cut income tax, particularly for the highest income groups, but have raised taxes on spending. In 1979, the top rate of income tax was 83% and the basic rate 33%; VAT was levied at 8%. Geoffrey Howe's first budget in June 1979 cut the top rate to 60% and the basic rate to 30%, while pushing VAT up to 15%. The next big move was made by Nigel Lawson in 1988, when he reduced the top rate to 40% (where it remains) and dragged the basic rate down to 25%. VAT was raised to 17.5% by Norman Lamont in 1991 to pay for the abolition of the poll tax. And the basic rate is now 22% courtesy of Gordon Brown.

All this has made the tax system less progressive because the rich, especially the top 1% of the population, have been the main beneficiaries of cuts in direct taxation. The poor spend a higher proportion of their incomes on goods that incur VAT and excise duties. Increases in income tax are now off the political agenda in Britain, with governments seeking other ways to raise revenues. So-called sin taxes on fuel, tobacco and - to a lesser extent - alcohol have been justified because the government would like us to cut consumption.

But do higher taxes really lead us to drive our cars less, give up the filthy weed and cut back on booze? Some sin taxes are more successful than others. The World Bank and the World Health Organisation said last week that a 10% increase on cigarette prices worldwide would reduce consumption by 4% in high-income countries and by 8% in low-income countries, persuading 42m people to give up smoking and saving 10m lives.

In a report aimed at cutting consumption in developing countries, the two organisations said government action to increase cigarette taxes would not lead to lower tax revenues in the medium to long term. Tax increases that raise the price of cigarettes by 10% worldwide would increase revenues by about 7% on average. "The evidence indicates that young people are more responsive to price changes than adults. Further studies indicate that people on low incomes and people with lower levels of education are also more responsive to price changes than wealthier, highly-educated people."

The picture for petrol is slightly more complex. The IFS says that a 1% increase in the real cost per mile of driving will reduce miles driven by less than 0.5%. "This is not a very large response, which suggests that any attempt to reduce reliance on the car by increasing the cost of fuel will not have been very successful."

The IFS findings show why the Dump the Pump campaign is proving unsuccessful. In the jargon of economists, demand for petrol is extremely price inelastic. We fill up regardless even when it hurts our purses and wallets.

While in general indirect taxes hurt the poor most, it is a slightly different story with fuel taxes because the poorest people in Britain do not own cars. As a result, the effect of higher fuel duties is felt most by those on middle incomes, according to the IFS. "If we take only households that own cars, the cost of living of the lowest (car-owning) income groups is the most adversely affected by the tax increase, with the effect becoming smaller as we move up the income distribution."

For the government, there are short- and long-term implications of all this. Firstly, the aims of ever-higher taxes on fuel tend to conflict. The very fact that demand for fuel is price inelastic means it is a wonderful source of revenue for the Treasury. If the government did succeed in deterring people from driving in significant numbers the result would be the loss of a valuable source of revenue.

Secondly, increasing the cost of filling up the tank hits the group that Labour has assiduously courted in recent years: those on middle incomes. Finally, while a cleaner and greener environment is a worthwhile goal, the chances of achieving that via escalating taxes on motorists looks pretty remote. People drive because they value their mobility and will only cease to use cars when there is a viable, cost-effective and reliable alternative. That means improvements - big improvements at that - in public transport, not just in rural areas but in the towns and cities as well.

 Larry Elliott is economic editor and Charlotte Denny economics reporter.

webTitle: British mining could fall to US group

fields.headline: British mining could fall to US group
fields.trailText: Britain's beleaguered coal industry could soon pass into American hands if Renco Group, a privately owned US industrial conglomerate, succeeds in buying RJB Mining.
fields.body:
Britain's beleaguered coal industry could soon pass into American hands if Renco Group, a privately owned US industrial conglomerate, succeeds in buying RJB Mining.

RJB Mining, owner of almost all the remaining deep mines, was picked as the successful bidder in the Tories' £815m privatisation of British Coal five years ago but has since run into trouble.

The company, run by Richard Budge, said in June that it was in talks with an undisclosed potential buyer.

Now it has emerged that Renco, the 49th largest business in the US, is the sole bidder. It is reported that Renco and Mr Budge have been in talks for more than three months and that a deal could be concluded within the next few weeks.

An RJB spokesman refused to comment on the stories but confirmed talks were progressing with a possible buyer, although he said no formal bid had been received.

Renco, which had sales of $2.5bn (£1.6bn) in 1999, was founded in 1980 by Ira Rennert, a former business consultant. His empire includes a range of companies, including Renco Steel, Rencoal, WCI Steel and AM General which manufactures the HumVee all-terrain military vehicle. The group employs 15,000 people.

A reclusive and controversial figure, Mr Rennert's interest in a magnesium mine in Utah once led to him being described by Hilary Clinton as "one of the biggest air polluters in America". He is also the owner of what is reputed to be America's largest private home, which is twice as big as the White House, on Long Island, New York.

There were many critics of Mr Rennert's expansive property. Building a house that size is like "sticking a thumb in our eyes", said author Kurt Vonnegut, who has had a home nearby for almost 25 years.

RJB, which employs around 7,000 people and operates 13 of the remaining 17 deep mines in Britain, has seen its shares slump to as low as 25p this year from 620p four years ago. They closed at 63.75p on Friday. While managing to repay the debt it took on to finance the privatisation, the company has been hit by the growing trend towards gas-fired power stations and cut-price imports, although it recently chalked up a big success by securing a valuable contract with AES of the US to supply Drax, Britain's largest power station, with coal.

Analysts said news of Renco's interest in RJB, which reported a pre-tax loss of £130m in 1999, should ease concerns that RJB will be sold to an asset stripper interested only in its valuable property portfolio. It has a land bank of more than 40,000 acres, although that includes waste tips and land at risk of subsidence which will be of little use for development.

However, an expected cost-cutting programme by Renco could put miners jobs at risk in Labour heartland, already suffering from the weakness of manufacturing industry.

Since 1947 the number of people employed in the coal industry has shrunk from 718,000 to 13,000 last year.

The Department of Trade and Industry recently announced plans to give a subsidy worth up to £100m to the ailing coal industry, subject to approval by the European commission. Of that amount, RJB is expected to receive £75m. A DTI spokeswoman said yesterday that the prospect of a takeover of RJB by Renco was " a matter for RJB and their shareholders".

webTitle: Leader: Has Labour got over its bad patch?

fields.headline: Summer of discontent
fields.standfirst:
Has Labour got over its bad patch?
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Rule number one for all who fish in these waters: never attach too much significance to a single opinion poll. What matters is the trend. If a poll is out of line with the trend, breathe deeply and wait to see if later polls confirm a new trend is upon us.
fields.body:
Rule number one for all who fish in these waters: never attach too much significance to a single opinion poll. What matters is the trend. If a poll is out of line with the trend, breathe deeply and wait to see if later polls confirm a new trend is upon us. Which means that the Conservatives should not be too disconsolate, nor Labour too overjoyed, at the Gallup poll in the Daily Telegraph at the end of last week which suggested that the government's summer blip might be over. The time for joy or disconsolation will be tomorrow, when the Guardian will give the results of its latest ICM poll.

Our guess is that the figures may give rather more pleasure to Labour than to the Conservatives. This comes from the sense that Labour in the past two or three weeks has wrested back control of the agenda. Before that, William Hague had been making the running and Labour was running scared. But then came Gordon Brown's announcement of a hefty, and overdue, boost for public spending. That thumped a message across which most people were eager to hear. We know, it said, that the services you depend on are nowhere near good enough and we plan to deploy all the resources we can to give you the deal you deserve. It is only a promise, of course, and promises have been broken before, and saying you mean to do something is a long way from delivering. But here at least was a message of hope: and engendering hope is good for political parties.

A further aspect of Gallup needs noting in the light of Labour's midsummer panic. The persistent theme of all those lugubrious memos - Philip Gould several times to Tony Blair, Tony Blair to his close associates - was that Labour had drifted out of touch with the electorate. Gallup seems to endorse that: 65% of respondents agreed with the Blair/Gould judgment that Tony Blair and his government were "somehow out of touch with gut British interests"; 32% disagreed. In a further show of solidarity with Labour's memo-producers, 55% per cent did not trust the government, against 41% who did.

These are worrying figures for a government not so far away from a general election. And yet they are only part of the picture. What Gallup suggested last week was that, while 65% faulted the government for failing to tap the national gut, a commanding 47% still none the less thought they would vote Labour in a general election tomorrow, against 32% (hardly better than at their nadir in 1997) who would back the Conservatives. And Labour had a 10-point lead over the Tories as the party best equipped to steer the nation through economic trouble; and a mighty 87% (including 79% of intending Conservative voters) backed the boost for government spending. Crucially, too, though this poll was taken too early to reflect any possible lift for Mr Hague from the news of his drinking feats in Rotherham in his youth, almost half the electorate rated Tony Blair as the leader best equipped to run the country, against just 22% (10 points below the figure of those who said they would vote Conservative) who think Mr Hague is the man for the job.

In other words: the government is not perfect; there is much that it needs to work on; but the nation sees it, quite rightly, as streets ahead of the only real alternative. On this evidence - we shall need to watch whether subsequent figures confirm the pattern - the kind of nervy improvisations which followed Philip Gould's warnings a couple of months ago may be at least as great a threat to its reputation as any of the omens that so much trouble its leader.

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst:
No 32: The printer

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No 32: The printer
fields.body:
Ostensibly there to improve the life of the worker - no more typewritten notes, blotted-out errors or complaints of carriage return elbow - the printer, in reality, fails to live up to its billing as a labour-saving device.

True, it can produce 100 copies of a memo before you summon the energy to leave your chair. Fancier models can collate and prioritise, number pages and collect them all in a neat pile to be transferred to in-tray or envelope. It's compact and quiet and, unlike fax machines, can generally be trusted not to mislay essential pages of essential documents.

So why is the printer not clutched closer to the bosom of the office worker? Perhaps it's because, although it has saved the secretary from inky fingers, it has thrust another responsibility into his or her lap: that of general repair man. Paper jam? Misfeed? Any other uninterpretable messages displayed blinkingly on the tiny screen? Alert the secretary.

Thus, instead of engineers, it is PAs and office managers who find themselves wriggling into the underbelly of the printer, manoeuvring past cogs and teeth and inexplicable sharp bits to remove stray shreds of A4. It is the admin assistant who is called upon to heave in another ream when colleagues worriedly report "paper empty" signals. And if it should run low on toner, expect hours of pleading for new stock from the suppliers and fielding casual updates from workmates ("just thought I should let you know").

The much put-upon secretary would, of course, be entirely justified in pulling the plug out and forcing the office to go back to basics (carbon paper, maybe?) for a day or two. But the prospect of confused managers prodding the printer (and the secretary) in vain attempts to switch the monster back on might be too much to contend with.

webTitle: The low down: The job market

fields.headline: The low down: The job market
fields.body:
It may be high summer, but the job market is not in a holiday mood, according to July figures in the report on jobs issued by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC). Though it has slowed, growth is still lively. In particular, demand for temps outstripped supply, pushing pay up at the fastest rate for two years.

Now that temps enjoy statutory holiday pay and a ready supply of work, perhaps the traditional seasonal pressure has increased as more temps go off for a summer break themselves.

A report from Warwick University provides a bigger picture of the job market over the next decade. Their Institute for Employment Research predicts 2.3m jobs will be created over the 1998-2009 period, and two-thirds of these will be taken by women. What's more, over that decade, 300,000 new managers will have to be found.

But the report also shows how the pattern of work has changed. The workplace is far less hierarchical than it was a generation ago. Time management and decision-making have devolved down. As a result, there is far more need for interpersonal skills, such as the ability to negotiate. So when employers speak of skills shortages these are what they mean. This is especially true of the secretarial job market, where customer service experience usually tops the list of skills in short supply. The REC suggests that one of the brakes on growth continues to be the difficulty employers have in finding suitably qualified candidates.

At the same time, the modern secretary is the model of the new worker. Having to cope with working for as many as 10 managers at a time naturally develops time management skills, assertiveness, and the ability to recognise priorities - albeit in a rather Darwinian fashion, because there is still very little training in these assets available to secretaries. All the same, the future promises to be an empowering experience.

webTitle: A short history of the secretary

fields.headline: A short history of the secretary
fields.standfirst: Things have moved a mile since Miss Moneypenny was the model. Or have they?  Claire Phipps  charts the evolution of the most essential asset in every office
fields.trailText: Things have moved a mile since Miss Moneypenny was the model. Or have they? Claire Phipps charts the evolution of the most essential asset in every office.
fields.body:
Who'd be a secretary? Back in 1969, the Times published a letter of advice to her - and it was, of course, always "her". Among the nuggets of wisdom offered to the nice young girl - and it was, of course, always a nice young girl - were the following gems: wear deodorant; learn how to make good tea and coffee; and always look beautiful, but not provocative. Changing stockings was an activity best confined to the "powder room".

Times have changed - sort of. Now there is a new set of rules for the secretary. Primary among them is the fact that she, or he, is probably no longer known as a secretary. Assistant, office manager, administrator or PA are far more likely to crop up when you ask the modern office worker what he or she does. But has the nitty-gritty of the role really changed from the days when buying presents for the boss's mistress was as much a part of the job as typing?

The Lipstick Years, BBC2's trawl through the changing lives of women in society, this week takes a peek into the office to see just how different today's secretary is from the "dollybird" of the past. Now that we have something approaching sexual equality (and laws against sexual harassment), the days of "staying behind after work" at the insistence of the boss are hopefully following the typewriter into obscurity.

But still there are new recruits, such as secretarial college student Rachel Moore, who admits that, when she starts working for a new boss, "I'd definitely do as much as I can to make him like me." She absolutely rules out sleeping her way into a job, but her statement reveals a lot about the modern secretary.

The job continues to require a high level of personal involvement - chemistry, if you like - with the boss; after all, the trusted PA will be party to any number of confidential conversations and correspondences. What's more, the boss is still all too often assumed to be a man; the secretary, by extension, a woman.

This wasn't always the case. Until the late 19th century, office admin was the preserve of men. It was only with the invention of the typewriter that women were permitted to take their first steps into the world of secretarial work.

Nimble fingers were not the only asset that the female secretary could bring to the job, though. "Getting on" with the boss was an integral part of the job description then, and contin ues to be to this day. Training respectable girls to be secretaries concentrated on honing this relationship. In the 60s, would-be secretaries at the Lucie Clayton school were taught the importance of deportment and make-up, along with more mundane skills such as diary management. Even as late as the 80s, says current principal Judith Kark, students would learn the best way to get out of a car and would, unbelievably, be regularly weighed. "We couldn't do it in the year 2000," she says. "I wouldn't do it in the year 2000. But we did it in the 80s. And everybody stepped on the scales."

Not surprisingly, it has traditionally been the boss who reaps the greater benefits from this unique working relationship. Betty Currie, personal secretary to Bill Clinton, was investigated after allegations that she had acted as a go-between in the president's affair with Monica Lewinsky - even visiting the former intern in the dead of night to retrieve "love tokens" (at overtime rates, we hope) - and had then been asked to cover up for him. Currie nevertheless described Clinton as "one of the nicest, most wonderful people" that she had worked for.

For most, keeping the boss happy is not such a legal minefield. Rose mary Nelson, working as a secretary in the 60s, recalls that "it was the rule that you please your boss, and that you do what he asked." For her, that meant wearing a miniskirt to the office at her employer's request. According to PA Anna Morgan, today's job description isn't all that different. "Men still view women as being able to do absolutely everything," she says.

Secretaries of whatever generation would be unsurprised by tales of walking the boss's dogs, picking up dry-cleaning or choosing presents for wives or mistresses. But the modern PA would surely balk at trimming the boss's eyebrows, a task delegated to secretary Marilyn Worlock back in the 50s.

The 21st-century secretary, though, has many more responsibilities than her predecessors, who were pretty much confined to the typing pool (until they married, and were packed off back to the home). Samantha Bond remembers of her days as a secretary, just 20 years ago, that she "typed letters, answered phones and made the coffee" - before escaping to a rather different role as Miss Moneypenny in the James Bond films.

Since the first Bond movie, Dr No - she and James Bond himself are the only characters to appear in every film - Moneypenny has embodied popular perceptions of the loyal secretary: always on duty, the soul of discretion and, naturally, just that little bit flirtatious with the hero. The character changed significantly, though, when Bond (Samantha, that is) took over, in Goldeneye. The modern Moneypenny is shown to have a life outside the office (bosses, take note), is permitted to answer back to James Bond's witticisms with a few of her own, and refers to him as "007" rather than the breathy "James" employed by her predecessors. The Bond series has reflected the changing situation in the office in more ways than one - Moneypenny is, of course, M's secretary, now played by the very female Dame Judi Dench.

It could have been very different. The inspiration for Ian Fleming's Moneypenny was Lady Ridsdale, a secretary in Naval Intelligence, where they both worked in the 40s. She left her job when she married, but later worked as her husband's secretary during his 38 years as a member of parliament.

The real advance for the PA today, though, is the knowledge that a job as a secretary can take her (or him) as far as they want to go. No need to resort to feminine wiles to persuade the boss that a little extra responsibility should be devolved your way. Sarah Morgan, PA to publicity guru Max Clifford, has no doubts that her job is crucial to the smooth running of the firm. "A PA nowadays is far more involved, almost the centre of a business," she insists. "Without me, I'd like to think that Max would find it extremely difficult to organise everything." She sees her job as a stepping stone and looks forward to the day when she has her own personal assistant to keep her working life in order.

There are those, though, who think the secretary has had her day. "In the future, a lot of the functions that secretaries and personal assistants do today will in fact be done by more automation," says Kenny Hirschhorn, a futurologist at Orange Media. "It's never easy to admit that a machine can do something more, better, faster than a human being, but that is the case of technology."

Others aren't so sure. A computerised PA wouldn't have to worry about deodorant, true. But neither could it make a cup of tea, filter out important phone calls from time-wasters, exercise perfect discretion or understand the boss's eccentricities. A personal assistant today is a lot more than a Palm Pilot on legs. Lots of people, after all, still want to be a secretary.

The Lipstick Years: Take Your Glasses Off, Miss Jones is on Wednesday at 9pm.

fields.headline: Would your boss seem as sweet by any other name?
fields.standfirst: The formal title is slipping out of the workplace. While some are hastening its exit, others refuse to let the honorific go.  Dolly Dhingra  reports
fields.trailText: The formal title is slipping out of the workplace. While some are hastening its exit, others refuse to let the honorific go. Dolly Dhingra reports.
fields.body:
What we would like to call the boss and what professional protocol demands of us might be two very different things. Two men with novel attitudes to their status in society have recently tested office attitudes to 21st-century formality.

First up was newly knighted Financial Services Authority chairman Howard Davies, who, by practising modesty in the workplace, is also raising funds for his favourite football team, Manchester City. Davies has imposed a penalty of £1 on anyone who dares calls him "Sir" - a title that no doubt comes loaded with one too many school-day memories.

It was an anonymous source that spilt the beans on their rather less reticent senior at BT, where Sir Peter Bonfield was apparently prepared to go global with his new title. Insiders claim that he has tacked his knighthood on to his email address - it now reads, rather loftily, sir.peter.bonfield@ ...

But who decides what we call the boss - them or us? Popular titles through the ages differ in sentiment and have included variations on guv, chief, boss, cheese, honcho or just plain old wanker. Opinion seems to be divided on how a name is arrived at.

"I think that it's not so much that you are obliged to call a boss by their title - I'd say if it was a very senior manager, you would address them as they wished," says Julie Amber, conference manager for the Industrial Society. "Partly because of their seniority and partly through courtesy. Titles confirm hierarchy and those that use them want that hierarchy emphasised." So what does she make of bosses who want to be addressed by their title? "I can understand that if someone has worked hard for a title and are proud of it, they would want it acknowledged, but I wouldn't do it myself," she says, diplomatically.

"It's certainly not a very empowering way to work. It creates an us-and-them situation with work ers and management, which usually results in people feeling that they don't really have a stake in their organisation. Hierarchy is a way to command and control and it certainly doesn't sit very well in the 21st century," Amber explains.

Rank and position aside, even the formal use of "Mr" is proving to be a bit too last-century for most. Judy Fisher, of recruitment consultants Judy Fisher Associates, says of her experience: "Of all our current clients I can think of only one boss who likes to be called Mr. It's very unusual these days for anyone not to be called by their first names. Our temps even call Sir Richard Eyre 'Richard'.

"I can only ever remember one of our clients, an elderly peer of the realm, who insisted on being called by his title. Even then everyone called him Lordy."

Richard Grace, managing director of secretarial recruiters Gordon Yates, believes that there is, however, a place for more formal attitudes in the office. "Titles are a bit like verbal dress codes. Nine times out of 10 you would formally address the boss the first time you met them as Mr, and Ms is always a good compromise," he says. "I would advise that you should not take too many liberties with names and to always err on the side of caution, unless otherwise advised."

Rachel Finbow, operations manager of Recruitment Employment Services, recommends waiting for a hint from the boss. "We tend to tell our workers to address bosses how they refer to themselves. Ninety-five percent of our bosses are referred to by their first names. It's only the old fashioned companies, such as surveyors, accountants and law firms, and usually the older clients, that want you to call them 'Mr So-and-so'."

Finbow believes that the thorny issue of whether to address a female boss as "Miss", "Mrs" or "Ms" can be avoided with an informal touch. "We've got lots of female bosses and I can't think of one who wants to be referred to by their surname," she says. "I would never advise using the term 'Ms'. People aren't comfortable with it and it certainly doesn't flow very easily." So, if "Mr" is too formal, and "Ms" too tricky, who could blame office workers for coming up with a name of their own? "Sir" and "Old fart" could, after all, be interchangeable titles.

fields.headline: UN to 'take back' unruly Mitrovice
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Tensions were rising in the northern Kosovo town of Mitrovice yesterday amid signs of an imminent security operation described by UN officials as an attempt to "regain control" of the region.
fields.body:
Tensions were rising in the northern Kosovo town of Mitrovice yesterday amid signs of an imminent security operation described by UN officials as an attempt to "regain control" of the region.

A company of the 2nd Battalion, Royal Fusiliers, was reported to have been drafted in from its base in Pristina.

Ten people were arrested in the Serb-dominated part of Mitrovice on Saturday night and a cache of grenades, ammunition and radios was seized by French K-For troops.

At the same time, a Serb radio station, Radio S, was ordered to close after UN officials said it had failed to apply for a broadcasting licence.

Reports in the local press have been predicting a raid on the lucrative Zvecan smelting works, which is part of the Trepca mining complex and has been blamed by the UN for high pollution levels in the town.

The factory, which ethnic Albanians long to control, is currently run by Serb authorities and employs at least 4,000 people.

UN sources have confirmed that more troops are being brought into Mitrovice to seize control of the factory; the commander of British troops in Pristina was seen talking to UN officials in the town yesterday.

Danish soldiers positioned to the north of the town are also expected to be redeployed to Mitrovice.

Officials say that the operation will be part of a broader attempt to establish the UN's control of the region; municipal authorities are expected to be targeted, with members of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling Serbian Socialist party, who have been accused of trying to wrest control of the town, arrested and expelled.

Mitrovice has been an embarrassment to the UN's mission in Kosovo since its peacekeeping troops took control of it in June 1999. Serb men, known as "bridge watchers", equipped with Motorola radios appear to control much of Mitrovice, stopping cars and checking people's identities.

The self-appointed leader of the Serb community in Mitrovice, Oliver Ivanovic, has predicted an angry reaction to plans to take over the smelter.

Mr Ivanovic said he was planning to hold demonstrations today if the factory is taken over.

"We have to deal with people's fear for their jobs. They are afraid for their future. They are afraid that K-For and [the UN administration] Unmik will bring in Albanians to the north [of the segregated town]."

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.standfirst: Michele Hanson
fields.body:
Offally fed up

"I 've found this horrible restaurant that serves gristle," said Olga, excitedly, the other day. "We must go." Why did she want to go again? Because the food was so staggeringly dreadful that she thought I should experience it, and because artists go there, and she is one.

So off we went for a girls' night out. Olivia joined us. On her last visit she had had an odd starter called "roots": a boiled egg in its shell and a bunch of carrots covered in blodges of dirt. But then, she likes a challenge.

I don't. I think one can take al dente too far. I could swear, for example, that chips are not meant to be al dente . They accompanied Olga's deep-fried tripe. Our new potatoes were hard and grubby, the liver thick and raw and the marrow bones a trip into hell. I have come across marrow bones before, in my mother's soups, so I speak from experience. The marrow should not come out like a wodge of pale, solid fat smelling like a butcher's shop on a bad day.

I asked the waitress to explain a bit of the menu and am fairly certain she was trying not to laugh out loud. I bet the staff rush back to the kitchen and fall about: "Ha, ha! That silly woman out there is eating her stinky raw marrow without a murmur!"

I must say I am sick of this modern brutalist lifestyle. Paint a joint stark white and serve crap to trendies and you can get away with anything. Last night I went to a party in a bleak white gallery and fell over a length of sticking-up cardboard. "That's the sculpture!" cried an agitated gentleman and brushed me aside. So I try to avoid this bleak stuff - grey, white, silver and glass, wobbly bridges, concrete bunkers, vast or minimalist interiors - and head for the heath.

Last week I approached a large tree. I experienced an odd but heavenly feeling in my chest and felt very fond of the tree. I tried a few more trees. Same again. Last year Rosemary's daughter married a tree. I thought her soppy at the time, but now I know she was on the right track. Where's my lavender oil?

webTitle: Simon O'Connell  - clothes are about to get technical

fields.headline: Fibre options
fields.standfirst: Touch your collar and your phone flickers into life. Tap your pocket and your CD player switches on. Sounds like sci-fi? Far from it, says  Simon O'Connell  - clothes are about to get technical
fields.trailText: Touch your collar and your phone flickers into life. Tap your pocket and your CD player switches on. Sounds like sci-fi? Far from it, says  Simon O'Connell  - clothes are about to get technical.
fields.body:
Fashion is about staying ahead of the game. Yet compared to other industries, such as car manufacture or telecommunications, the clothing industry is backward, and fashion designers deeply conservative. Apart from the odd technical fibre here and utility pants there, clothes are made in much the way they were 2,000 years ago: spin fibre into thread, weave thread into cloth, cut into pieces, then sew back together again. This is about to change.

Few fashion designers will be prepared for the first collection from three visionary partners when it goes on sale later this month. Levi's ICD+ is an unprecedented collaboration between Philips, Europe's largest electronics company, Levi's, one of the world's largest clothing manufacturers, and designer Massimo Osti, who was last year voted most influential designer of the 90s by menswear magazine Arena Homme Plus. Between them, the trio hope to produce the first really credible, successful range of technical clothing. The first ICD+ range incorporates Philips mobile phone and MP3 technology into a range of jackets designed by Osti and made by Levi's.

But the project goes much further than jeans with mobile phone pockets. Superficial "utility-look" clothing is over: this is a serious attempt to merge fashion and electronics. "Levi's heritage is based on the tradition of workwear, but our first miner's pants were launched in 1873 - we needed to examine what people need from workwear today. We identified a group we call nomads who are constantly on the move, always in taxis or airports and need to be wired, so we began looking for partners," says Peter Ingwersen, of Levi's.

Philips has been working away quietly for years on a project called Philips Wearable Electronics, and this collaboration with Levi's is the first to bear fruit. The project mission statement is "Philips technology in every shirt and skirt" and the result will be widely available following this autumn's launch.

The electronics group envisions a future in which all garments will contain micro-computers. "This first collection is the equivalent of laying the first brick in The Great Wall of China. Our goal is to give the objects around us intelligence, so they become our subjects, and this includes our clothes," says Stefano Marsano, managing director of Philips Design.

Philips is not alone in developing wearable electronics, but it is leading the field. Watch manufacturers including Swatch, Casio and Citizen have announced that they are developing wrist phones, pagers, ski passes and translators. fields.headline: Suits you, madam
fields.standfirst: Zandra Rhodes's new museum was sure to be a shocker.  Jonathan Glancey explores fashion made concrete
fields.trailText: Zandra Rhodes's new museum was sure to be a shocker. Jonathan Glancey explores fashion made concrete.
fields.body:
Zandra Rhodes's fashion museum, which is due to open in Bermondsey, south London, in 2002, was fated to be colourful. The famous designer has always made a splash; she looks as exotic as a cockatoo crossed with a punk bird of paradise. Her choice of architect, the 69-year-old Mexican Ricardo Legorreta, seems exactly right. His love of vibrant colour is a perfect match for Rhodes's. Legorreta has designed a wide range of buildings inspired by Mexican tradition. He likes "the supremacy of solid over voids, the use of colour to enclose wall space". His is an architecture, in other words, that is colourful and substantial and yet, adopting the best from the Modern movement, diffused with light. This year he won the American Institute of Architects' Gold Medal. His fashion museum stands out in Bermondsey as brightly as a Rhodes frock at a masonic dinner.

The Zandra Rhodes Museum of Fashion should provide a chance to rethink the relationship between architecture and fashion. It is said, limply, that architecture is "fashion able" today, as if it has ever been out of sight and mind. What is certain is that architecture and fashion move remarkably closely together at some points in history.

In recent times, there was a wonderfully funny time - the mid-80s - when you could witness, in London at least, roosts of black-clad young things in the very latest square-cut, matt-black Japanese designer togs perched self-consciously in new bars and cafes that were almost indistinguishable in form and spirit from the clothes on grim parade.

Let's go further back in history. Take the early-14th century. Now, imagine yourself in Salisbury watching the last stones of the 404ft spire being winched into place. Down below are gathered some grandees. Look at the womenfolk. Some are wearing steeple hats, as vertiginously Gothic as the spire of the ambitious cathedral, while their long, brilliantly embroidered gowns are as rich and as decorative as the frescoed walls inside the long, tall nave of the magnificent church. Here, for a special moment, couture and cathedral, fashion and architecture are in near- perfect harmony. The lofty ideals of knightly chivalry, too, are somehow wrapped up in this meeting of Gothic cloth and stone. The pointed Early English architecture of the sky- piercing cathedral also recalls the suits of armour that were perfected, aesthetically, at this time: a fully armoured knight resembled a kind of kinetic Gothic building.

Leap now, across a void of 300 years, across the full-blown Gothic of the 15th century, across the great houses of the 16th and 17th centuries, across the Baroque dome of Wren's St Paul's and land discreetly in front of a new Palladian house, say, Chiswick, by Lord Burlington, or Mereworth by Colen Campbell. Palladian architecture, all the vogue in Britain and Ireland between 1715 and 1740, was a mathematically correct, chaste and polite form of design that went scented-hand-in-silk-glove with the rise of the much celebrated "English" gentleman. The dress of a Lord Burlington or a Colen Campbell was handsome yet constrained compared with, say, the foppishness of the French or the glittery braggadocio of the Italians.

Just as the spare dress of the English gentleman matched and mirrored the cool grace of Palladian architecture, so the flamboyant garb of his Italian contemporary - certainly by the 1740s - was a richly engraved foil to the extravagant curlicues of newly fashionable Rococo architecture. As rich as a box of the most improbable Italian chocolates, Rococo was a style too far for the relatively sedate British, who were often appalled by the sheer, unmitigated extravaganza (or vulgarity) of the land that had given them, via Andrea Palladio in the Veneto and Inigo Jones at home, the very Palladian strictures and structures that they had made so much their own.

It was, perhaps, from the beginnings of Romanticism towards the end of the 18th century that architecture and fashion became self-consciously related. As the passion for all things Gothic grew, wealthy architects started to look the part, dressing up first as monks and, later, the most intense Goths began to dress in more or less authentic garb. This, though, was less a coincidence or tailored match between architec ture and fashion, than a form of wilful eccentricity, or perversity. Even so, as Gothic Revival twisted its way into the Aesthetic movement and art nouveau it sometimes became difficult to tell the new Wildean residents of, say, deeply fashionable Chelsea, from their furniture and fittings.

The Modern movement, an iconoclastic response to the perceived architectural excesses of the 19th century, saw the re-emergence of severe, almost classical dress among its protagonists and clients. Look at Le Corbusier or Mies van der Rohe as they walked together through the radical white housing complex they designed, in Stuttgart in 1927; in their sombre coats, bankers' hats, brollies and polished shoes they look every bit the "English" gentleman. As their houses were a kind of one-step back, two-steps forwards take on the classical tradition (Le Corbusier's famous Villa Savoye, Poissy, 1929-31 was identified by the critic Colin Rowe writing in the Architectural Review in the early 50s as a take on a Palladian villa), so they adopted the sombre garb of a sober gent.

Of course all this may simply be a case of architecture as self-portraiture. The peerless architectural cartoonist Louis Hellman quotes, in his book Archi-tetes, Samuel Butler's The Way of all Flesh: "Every man's work, whether it be literature or music or architecture or anything else, is always a portrait of himself". The "id in the grid", as Hellman shows in his cartoons, is there for anyone with a sharp, and perhaps a little inventive, eye to see. Just as dog-owners have a delightful tendency to look like their dogs, architects can look disturbingly like their buildings.

Even so, the connection between moments in fashion and movements in architecture are intriguing; they are there for you to dig out if you want to, for buildings are in many ways a representation of ourselves, our bodies and the ways in which we clothe ourselves. We build facades for ourselves, not just for our buildings. Zandra Rhodes looks like her new museum and her new museum will look like her. It's an honourable tradition in the history of our culture and both should be flattered.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Anatomists Of Desire/ On The Line
fields.body:
Albert D Lasker was the sort of character your mother warned you against. Son of a Texan banker, he made his living by peddling lies and regularly sacking a high proportion of his staff just to encourage the rest. It goes almost without saying that he became a key figure in shaping the 20th century, having more or less single-handedly invented the modern advertising industry. Alan Taylor recalls his doubtful record in the first of a new series, Anatomists Of Desire (11.0am, Radio 4).

According to a report in The Lancet, rugby players face more risk of serious injury than any other sportsmen. The journal revealed that an average of 14 players get hurt for every 1,000 hours of play, often with injuries as life-threatening as a broken neck. Yet, as On The Line (7.30pm, Radio 5 Live) reveals, many clubs and national associations still do not take out adequate insurance to compensate disabled players.
