fields.headline: Rough and ready
fields.standfirst: A host of raucous traditional Scottish songs - including the original version of Auld Lang Syne - are about to resurface.  Alfred Hickling reports
fields.trailText: A host of raucous traditional Scottish songs - including the original version of Auld Lang Syne - are about to resurface.
fields.body:
Auld Lang Syne may be Robbie Burns's greatest hit, but how many people realise that the ubiquitous New Year singalong was not a Burns original but an ancient folk song that had never appeared in print until the poet took it down for inclusion in the Scots Musical Museum?

Though it sounds like a mausoleum for old fiddles and bagpipes, the Scots Musical Museum is not a building but a book. It was published in six volumes between 1787 and 1803 and was intended to form "the Text Book and standard of Scottish Song and Music". Robert Burns was its chief curator and devoted virtually the final decade of his life to the project, having become, he declared, "Absolutely crazed about it."

Burns's enthusiasm was founded on the premise that his native, oral folk tradition was packed with ancient tunes that were too good to lose. Working under commission from the Edinburgh music publisher James Johnson, and refusing to accept a single penny for what he considered to be his patriotic duty, Burns set about collecting famous tunes and patching up those that had been part-forgotten in order to preserve for posterity their "wild happiness of thought and expression".

Posterity has taken a while to respond. Although successive editions of the Scots Musical Museum have appeared in print, it has tended to remain the preserve of specialists rather than a text aired for its entertainment value. This year, however, the Museum is to return to the concert room for a series of late-night recitals running throughout the Edinburgh international festival.

The informal concerts, under the banner of Work, Sex and Drink, have been programmed by singers Kirsteen McCue - an academic specialist on 18th-century music publishing who frequently presents on BBC Radio 3 - and Sheena Wellington, a driving force behind the current renaissance of Scottish traditional music, who was invited to sing at the inauguration of the Scottish parliament.

McCue and Wellington represent a meeting of the "classical" and "folk" traditions, whose apparent separation only really came about in the 200 years since the Musical Museum appeared. Burns was himself, however, acutely aware of the refinement of middle-class taste which threatened to eclipse the popular art of the period. "Ignorance and Prejudice may perhaps affect to sneer at the simplicity of the poetry or music of some of these pieces," he wrote, "but their having been for ages the favourites of Nature's Judges - the Common People - was for me a sufficient test of their merit."

Kirsteen McCue argues that it wasn't so much extinction that threatened these songs as the dubious fate of being dressed up for middle-class consumption. "The Scots Musical Museum was not the first attempt to anthologise ancient Scottish song," she says. "The antiquarian impulse to preserve the Scots heritage largely stemmed from consequences of the Union with England in 1707. But it was also part of the broader European Enlightenment. The Encyclopaedia Britannica originated in Edinburgh around the same time, whilst a rival music publisher, George Thomson, solicited new settings of Scots lyrics from Haydn, Weber and Beethoven."

The efforts of Thomson and his ilk could be interpreted as making the music of the crofter's cottage presentable for genteel drawing-rooms. Burns's great influence, Allan Ramsay, even styled himself "a song-broker to ladies" - though there is plenty in Burns's later collection that would make Ramsay's target audience topple from their piano stools. The Scots Musical Museum was not only the first song collection to be conceived as a practical, pocket-sized com pendium, it was the only anthology to admit songs in their natural state without any editorial interference.

"There is an abundance of songs in which lassies lose their silken snoods," concedes Wellington, "and before you ask, we don't have it in mind to sing Nine Inches Will Please a Lady. There are plenty of genuinely spooky supernatural tunes as well; and we are also devoting an evening to some of the highly inflammatory Jacobite songs, which Burns was not afraid to include."

Unlike contemporary publications offering fanciful new arrangements, the Scots Musical Museum captures melody in the raw - often nothing more elaborate than a single line for vocalist or fiddle-player with a rudimentary bass accompaniment. The actual performance of the songs, therefore, leaves much to the musicians' imagination.

"I think this helps to keep the songs alive," reasons McCue, "even when a song from an oral tradition, once committed to paper, can no longer be said to belong to an oral tradition at all."

"We want the concerts to have a 'busky' feel," adds Wellington. "It shouldn't be too staid. We have chosen to work with the cream of the classical and traditional Scots singers and instrumentalists and we asked them to interpret the songs how they will. We intend to get up and fair enjoy ourselves."

The series Work, Sex and Drink: Scots and Their Songs is in rep at the Hub (0131-473 2000) from August 15 to September 1.

fields.headline: A brief history of love
fields.standfirst: Stephen Hawking is furious about a new play about his marriage and beliefs.  Veronica Lee  asks its author why he thinks Hawking is fair game
fields.trailText: Stephen Hawking is furious about a new play about his marriage and beliefs. Veronica Lee asks its author why he thinks Hawking is fair game.
fields.body:
How would you feel if your life, warts and all, formed the subject of a play that hundreds of people could see each night? That's the question raised by God and Stephen Hawking, in which a terrible disease encourages a great scientist to question the existence of God. And Hawking doesn't like it: earlier this month he told Physics World magazine that he found the play "deeply offensive and an invasion of my privacy".

Robin Hawdon, the play's author, describes the work as "a debate between conventional religious beliefs and scientific discoveries about the origins of the universe". So why has he chosen to structure it around Hawking's personal life? "It's very hard to dramatise those concepts without dramatising the context in which they were conceived," says Hawdon. "And as Hawking was the first scientist to communicate that fact to lay people, he was the obvious person to use for the purpose. And his illness [Hawking has to use a wheelchair as a result of motor neurone disease] is dramatic in itself."

Hawdon has had no direct verbal or written exchanges with the author of A Brief History of Time; he has spoken only to Hawking's personal assistant, who has indicated Hawking's lack of enthusiasm for the project, which has been a few years in the making. "I didn't approach him straight away," says the playwright. "When I had written the first draft, I sent it off and his people said he had received it, but I didn't hear any more."

Then Hawking's ex-wife, Jane, published her memoir of their life together, Music to Move the Stars. This seemed to open up new possibilities for Hawdon's play, whose big themes and big characters - God, Einstein, Newton, the Pope - needed a more human scale.

Jane Hawking, says Hawdon, made "quite helpful suggestions". But given that Stephen left her and married his nurse, doesn't the former Mrs Hawking have an axe to grind? "I've tried to resist any suggestions that slant things in her favour," says the writer. "There is a delicate line between spurious intrusion and clever dramatisation of the known facts."

Hawdon could always have called his lead character Professor Bloggs and given him a different form of illness. "But then everyone would still have said it was about Hawking," he says. "It seems to me that if you make it comic, or a pastiche, then you can be as rude or as defamatory as you like. Nobody seems to sue over that because they're terrified of being thought of as a pseud. However, if you write a vaguely serious piece...

"In any case, the play is not specifically about Professor Hawking's private life, or his relationships. He is used symbolically to stand for science and for the march of modern technology. Jane is a devout Christian and Stephen is an agnostic, and that became one of the main dramatic arguments in the play."

Hawdon says his play is a celebration of a remarkable life and career. Anyway, he adds, Hawking is in the public domain: he is "always on telly".

So will Hawdon be giving Hawking a share of any profits the play may bring in? "He doesn't need it," the writer replies. "He's already a hugely wealthy man - much more so than I am."

God and Stephen Hawking is at the Theatre Royal, Bath (01225 448844) from August 23-26, then touring.

That's the question raised by God and Stephen Hawking, in which a terrible disease encourages a great scientist to question the existence of God. And Hawking doesn't like it: earlier this month he told Physics World magazine that he found the play "deeply offensive and an invasion of my privacy". fields.headline: The camera never lies
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Building Of The Year/The Name Of This Film Is Dogme 95/Movie Virgins/Wildlife On One
fields.body:
Buildings: without them you'd get cold and wet. And people would be able to nick your stuff when you went out (not that it'd be going "out" if there was nothing to exit from). And you'd have to mark out your territory with piles of jackets like make-do goalposts in the park lest someone invaded your space when you weren't there. Or you could live in a cave, but there aren't as many as there used to be. Which begs the question: where have all the caves gone?

Of course, it's not just practicality that makes buildings great. It's the aesthetic that captivates us, inspires awe. Architecture, is, as Goethe said, frozen music. In Building Of The Year (C4, Sun), Waldemar Januszczak gave us a tour of the contenders for the Stirling Prize, the Royal Institute of British Architects' accolade for the greatest new building, and each, in its own way, was a glacial concerto.

From the Kilder Belvedere deep in the Northumbrian forest to the London Eye and Canary Wharf Station, from Latern House in the Lake District - which looked like JK Rowling had had a hand in its design - to my personal favourite, the Great Glasshouse at the National Botanic Garden of Wales, these were constructs which defined the here and now and will be how posterity remembers the early days of the 21st century. All curves, circles, domes and crescents, with nary a phallic tower among them, these buildings perhaps say more about our aesthetic development than any other field of art.

Yet all the while the camera fetishised the curves of steel and arcs of glass, there was the nagging feeling that each building would be a bugger to clean. How would the Shuttleworths keep the crescendo of windows on their Los Angeles-esque home smearless? Short of sending in a team of acrobats armed with Mr Muscle, how would the giant spokes of the London Eye maintain their gleamy whiteness? And how long before dust, dead bluebottles and litter sullied the underground cathedral of Canary Wharf Station? The panes of glass in Wales's Great Glasshouse were so strong you could walk on them, we were told, and so would be easy to clean. But what a lot of newspaper and vinegar you'd need.

Who would have thought arthouse film-making methodology could be made so interesting, funny and smart? Yet this is exactly what The Name Of This Film Is Dogme 95 (C4, Sat) achieved. Under the auspices of Richard Kelly, the film was a wholesome treat - vitamin-enriched ice cream, if you will - topped off with nuts (or at least, the slightly crackers Lars von Trier) and a sprinkling of Paprika Steen, Dogme 95's leading actress.

Explaining the Dogme movement's "vow of chastity" between clips of films like Festen and The Idiots, Kelly's documentary pastiched its subject whilst illuminating it wonderfully. With input from film-makers, critics and the excellent Paprika (whose porn name might indeed be Cumin Mee), this was exemplary stuff. And oddly funny, especially when Soren Kragh-Jacobsen, one of the original Dogme brotherhood, compared the movement to Eric Clapton Unplugged.

The Movie Virgins (C4, Sun) continued on their compelling-as-a-car-crash missions to make their first feature film. Alex was in Cannes trying to persuade Jude Law to star in his movie, while things were getting fraught in Leon's house as filming got under way, Leon coming over all autocratic and visionary. You could only laugh.

The best moment of schadenfreude came when Alex actually met Jude, and Jude was snootily non-plussed by the wannabe director. As Jude and wife Sadie Frost were interviewed by Barry Norman - presumably to publicise their complete turkey of a movie, Final Cut - Alex waited patiently for a word in the actor's shell-like. He got half a syllable in before Jude stalked off with Nick Moran, shrieking "Does anyone have any cigarettes?" (Bizarre how these people are considered famous when the last thing Nick Moran did was a Barclays ad). As it turned out, Paul Nicholls read for the part, and we are on tenterhooks as to whether he'll take a part in the "clubland thriller, Sorted". We can only hope not.

The thieving ways of Yogi Bear are alive and well in the bears of Yosemite National Park as Wildlife On One (BBC1, Sun) demonstrated. Like actors, bears are wonderfully cute until you see them at close quarters, when they are needy and snarling. Not a pretty sight at all.

webTitle: Ex-BBC boss says Blair is a philistine

fields.headline: Ex-BBC boss says Blair is a philistine
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The government's promise of extra money for the arts is "a charade to mask its utter philistinism", a former controller of Radio 3 claimed in an outspoken tirade last night.
fields.body:
The government's promise of extra money for the arts is "a charade to mask its utter philistinism", a former controller of Radio 3 claimed in an outspoken tirade last night.

Sir John Drummond, who also ran the Proms and the Edinburgh Festival, said that despite the vow of £100m increase in arts spending after the next election, Tony Blair was a "puritan" who believed "these vagabonds must be kept on short rations".

He said that the government "know nothing about culture and they don't really care. You can tell what kind of a man the prime minister is by his choice on Desert Island Discs. Rock bands that have disappeared, Rule Britannia and Ivanhoe - I suppose that was the last book he read."

Sir John, 65, a fierce critic of successive Tory governments who has kept his powder dry up to now on New Labour, said that even worse than its failure to support the arts properly was the government's "fetish" for dismissing anything that might be seen as elitist.

"Chris Smith [the culture secretary] is walking round saying everything is solved, " he said. "Well, nothing has been solved. When I told him this recently we had a stand-up fight. Just making bland noises about more money coming some time in the future is not good enough. All this money is only really coming in four or five years' time. Well, I'm sorry, but regional theatre in particular may not be around to receive it then."

He went on: "The real low point for me was a few months ago when the greatest artists and writers in the country were invited to Downing Street to be told by some prat from Wolverhampton that information technology is culture. On the contrary, it is a delivery system like a telephone. It has bugger all to do with culture. Yet this chap was introduced to us by Tony Blair himself and then thanked by Cherie... We were all of us, Salman Rushdie, Richard Eyre and Trevor Nunn included, put in a room and told that we are inflexible and incompetent and have achieved nothing in our lives."

Sir John's attack came at the Edinburgh International Book Festival, where he was reading from his autobiography, Tainted By Experience, published next month.

Even his publisher, Lord Evans, who runs Faber & Faber, was attacked for displaying typical "bully boy language" in telling museums that they had to be more like "Hard Rock cafes" if they were to pull in the public, when he took over the government's new museums, libraries and archives commission.

Sir John, who chairs the Theatres Trust, said that a brain drain was threatening the very survival of theatre in this country, and with four more 2,000-seater new lottery-funded auditoriums coming on stream this year, there was no money "to put anything on in them."

The state of regional theatre was alarming. "People talk about meltdown and it's true. We are in a situation where we are governed by people with no natural sense of culture. Once there were people in the House of Commons of real culture, like Michael Foot or Ted Heath. Look around now, and who is there?"

He reserved his most savage criticism, however, for former colleagues at the BBC, dismissing Alan Yentob as "a prat" who personified the problem of a dumbed down culture where "the idea of qualitative judgment had gone," he said. "All Yentob is interested in is films and rock music. There is this infantalism everywhere of middle-aged men in baseball caps turned round the wrong way who don't want to grow up."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Man In The White Suit/Elizabeth/Mir Chronicles: A Life In Space/La Reine Margot
fields.body:
The Man In The White Suit

(Alexander Mackendrick, 1951)

7am, Carlton Cinema

Not just any old white suit... Inventor Alec Guinness creates a material in his hubble-bubbling apparatus that lasts forever, never gets dirty, and brings him nothing but trouble. Capitalist bosses Cecil Parker and Ernest Thesiger and the unions are all completely aghast at a creation that could put them out of business. It might all sound serious, but this is a satirical Ealing comedy that'll have you in stitches - and Guinness's deadpan act was one of his best performances.

Elizabeth

(Shekhar Kapur, 1998)

8pm, FilmFour

Kapur's account of the young Elizabeth I's rise to the throne may not be entirely accurate but it's a convincing picture of a dangerous time. Courtly intrigue is carried out with whispers in dark, stony corridors and the cold strike of the stiletto. Around the young queen are calculating politicians like Chris Eccleston's Norfolk and Geoffrey Rush's Walsingham, while her lover, Joseph Fiennes' Dudley, lacks resolve. Cate Blanchett's Elizabeth rises above all this, creating a fiery monarch reminiscent of Bette Davis in her regal authority. And Eric Cantona too.

Mir Chronicles: A Life In Space

10pm, Discovery

A potted history of space travel, and the rivalry between the superpowers. The USSR was the first to launch a rocket into space, but then the US gained the ultimate advantage with their lunar landing. This so irritated the Russians that they switched their attentions to building space stations on which cosmonauts could live. Mir (or, ironically, "peace") was the culmination of their efforts.

La Reine Margot

(Patrice Chéreau, 1994)

10.15pm, FilmFour

An elegant, savage romance about the 17th-century massacre of the Huguenots, based on Dumas' hefty novel. Sumptuous sets and hacking swordplay, but none of it overpowers the acting - Isabelle Adjani is a luscious Marguerite de Valois, slipping out of her arranged marriage with the king (Daniel Auteuil) to be with dashing blade Vincent Perez, a latterday Flynn.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous: Mickey Rourke in Body Heat.
fields.body:
Mickey Rourke in Body Heat (Lawrence Kasdan, 1981)

Who? Mickey was the 80s, thanks to two memorable roles: The Motorcycle Boy in Rumble Fish (1983) and John in everyone's favourite softcore movie Nine1/2 Weeks (1986). He was strong, silent and sexy. But not for long. His personal obsessions with boxing, drinking and the IRA led to critically derided fare like Homeboy (1988, boxing), Barfly (1987, drinking) and A Prayer For The Dying (1987, the IRA). He hit a low point with 1991's Harley Davidson And The Marlboro Man, co-starring with Don Johnson. The whole of the 90s was a bit of a career low for Rourke, who diversified into professional boxing, became co-owner of a West Hollywood gym and got arrested for spousal abuse in 1994. But he did manage to make one good film in the 90s. Vincent Gallo got a great performance from Rourke - as a bookie in his directorial debut, Buffalo 66. And there might be hope for Rourke yet, set to star in a new, incredibly violent, version of Get Carter and, with Gallo, in Peaces Of Ronnie.

The role: Teddy Lewis, criminal acquaintance of sleazy Florida lawyer Ned (William Hurt).

Best line: When Ned wants Teddy's help, Teddy says: "Any time you try a decent crime you got 50 ways you can fuck up. If you can think of 25 of them then you're a genius. And you ain't no genius."

Cringe factor: Low. It's pretty much the same role that Rourke played for most of his early career. It's what happened to him later that makes you want to cringe.

Other wannabes: Ted Danson, pre-Cheers, but post-hairpiece.

Critical judgement: Roger Ebert, Chicago Sun-Times: "Body Heat is good enough to make film noir play like we hadn't seen it before."

Also not starring in: Steven Spielberg's 1979 comedy 1941, as Private Reese.

Body Heat, Sky Cinema, Wednesday August 16, 10pm.

webTitle: Nato fears Karadzic is about to escape

fields.headline: Nato fears Karadzic is about to escape
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Nato governments are coming under renewed pressure to seize Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader indicted by a tribunal in the Hague for war crimes, amid rumours that he is planning to flee to Serbia.
fields.body:
Nato governments are coming under renewed pressure to seize Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader indicted by a tribunal in the Hague for war crimes, amid rumours that he is planning to flee to Serbia.

Mr Karadzic is believed to be hiding under heavy guard near Pale, in Serb-controlled eastern Bosnia-Herzegovina, where French soldiers are controlling the international peacekeeping force, S-For.

The French have been criticised for not being robust enough towards indicted war criminals; two years ago, a French military intelligence officer was summoned to Paris after he was alleged to have warned Mr Karadzic of plans to kidnap him.

Western diplomats say, however, that the French are preparing to adopt a more aggressive approach, while admitting that Mr Karadzic can not be taken without the help of the US forces, whose sector in north-east Bosnia borders on the French one. Only the Americans, diplomats say, have the necessary intelligence resources - human and technical - to seize Mr Karadzic. "They are watching him all the time," one diplomat said.

Recent press reports expressing Nato's determination to capture Mr Karadzic appear to have been prompted by rumours of his impending flight to Serbia, where he will be outside S-For's mandate.

webTitle: Dewar returns to face exam chaos

fields.headline: Dewar returns to face exam chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, returns to work today after major heart surgery to face demands that he sack his education minister, Sam Galbraith, over a school exam results fiasco.
fields.body:
Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, returns to work today after major heart surgery to face demands that he sack his education minister, Sam Galbraith, over a school exam results fiasco.

Mr Galbraith, who met education officials and representatives from the Scottish qualifications authority yesterday in an attempt to resolve the shambles surrounding the distribution of exam certificates, has insisted he will not stand down. Following the talks, the authority said all 147,000 results would be rechecked.

But the Scottish National party said Mr Galbraith's credibility had been irreparably damaged. "The education minster must be sacked because of his startling ineptitude," said the outgoing SNP leader, Alex Salmond. "Galbraith is trying to distance himself from the breakdown in the exam results process, yet he was deeply involved in pushing through the administrative and IT changes."

On Saturday, Ron Tuck, the authority's chief executive, resigned, accepting full responsibility for the fiasco which left thousands of pupils uncertain about their grades and their chances of further education. Computer problems and a new examination structure have been blamed.

About 2,000 certificates which should have been sent to students on Thursday were not posted on time; hundreds more students received incomplete results; many schools will not be sent details of the results until this week; and universities were not given the results in time to advise pupils on admission. Authority officials have admitted they do not know how many results have been affected.

Lindsay Paterson, professor of education policy at Edinburgh University, said that all pupils' results must now be cast into doubt. "I can't see how the universities and employers can possibly have any confidence that any of the results that have been issued are reliable. It's scandalous."

But Mr Galbraith said there was no evidence to suggest the exam results were invalid. "There is absolutely no evidence whatsoever to suspect ... that any of the results are invalid," he said. "Many of the so-called mistakes cited are in fact just a lack of understanding of the results."

Following yesterday's meeting, the authority chairman, David Miller, said it would be running checks to confirm its computer processes accurately recorded candidates' results. The checks will apply to all candidates but priority will be given to those who have applied for university places.

This will be completed by Thursday, allowing universities and colleges to confirm places to candidates from the following day.

A joint statement from the authority and Mr Galbraith said: "The major issue is still one of missing data, not of inaccurate results. There is no reason to doubt the accuracy of the majority of certificates."

fields.headline: No: 1698
fields.standfirst: Sophie Ellis-Bextor
fields.trailText: Sophie Ellis-Bextor
fields.body:
Age: A precocious 21.

Appearance: Chirpy, cheepy pixie.

Occupation: The real Posh Spice.

Qualifications for the title: She went to the fee-paying Godolphin and Latymer school in London. And her mum is Janet Ellis, the nicely spoken one off Blue Peter.

Not quite blue-blooded, though. Don't be picky. Anyway, Passnotes has already done all the photogenic royals.

So what are the original Posh's thoughts on her young usurper? Mrs Beckham is probably less concerned about the elfin one's pedigree than the possibility of being beaten to the top of the pop charts this Sunday.

So, the sticky-backed plastic girl is on course to pip the Spice Girls? Not quite. It's been a long time coming, but Vicky's first solo-ish effort, a duet with Dane Bowers (another teen band refugee), is released today. So, unfortunately, is Miss E-B's ditty, Groovejet (If This Ain't Love), a cross between Stardust's summer catchiness and the pop-lite warblings of theaudience.

Thewotsit? Sophie's annoyingly named previous band. You may recall their brief brush with airplay, A Pessimist Is Never Disappointed.

No. Am I to assume that Sophie will be nursing a half-empty pint and maintaining a downbeat attitude towards her imminent pop stardom? "I'm very excited," she admits, "but I'm trying not to think about number one too much because then I'll think we haven't done too well if it goes in at five."

Five? Heaven forbid! Don't joke. Victoria certainly doesn't think it's funny. After belatedly following her fellow Spices into a solo career, she now faces the ignominy of losing out to her younger rival in both the musical and classiness battle.

A bit of posh: "Sophie really is posh," points out loyal mum Janet. "She doesn't need a nickname."

A bit of spice: Janet Ellis left Blue Peter in 1987 after it was revealed that she was a single mother.

Not to be confused with: Sophie Rhys-Jones, Bret Easton Ellis, Posh Spice.

webTitle: Poland's breeders fear the end of a line

fields.headline: Poland's breeders fear the end of a line
fields.trailText: "They're not just horses, they're living Rembrandts," Charlie Watts insisted. "And if it was up to me I'd keep them wrapped in cotton wool, daring to take a peek at them only every once in a while."
fields.body:
"They're not just horses, they're living Rembrandts," Charlie Watts insisted. "And if it was up to me I'd keep them wrapped in cotton wool, daring to take a peek at them only every once in a while."

On Saturday the Rolling Stone and his wife Shirley paid £140,000 for two pure-bred Polish Arabs at the 31st horse auction at Poland's oldest stud, Janow Podlaski.

Their bids were the highest for any of the 33 lots, and their reward was a ride round the stadium in a Habsburg-era imperial coach, drawn by six white stallions and cheered on by the locals.

The chestnut 15-year-old called Alejka and a speckled grey five-year-old called Euza will be taken to the Watts's stud in Devon later this week, to live alongside 140 other Arabs, most of them from Poland.

Mrs Watts has great hopes for her new mares: Euza's sire is an international champion, and Alejka was the 1993 Polish national champion.

"It's all in the lineage," she said, happy to have beaten an anonymous telephone bid from England. "All the Polish Arabians can be traced back 20 generations or more to desert-born Arabians".

Delicate copper-plate entries in the Janow stud book prove her point. But the future of the 180-year old Janow and Poland's 34 other state studs is far from certain. Having survived two world wars and the communist regime, they are now struggling to make their way in the market economy.

Twenty-seven studs are due to be privatised or closed in the next few years. The process has already begun.

Izabella Pawelec-Zawadzka, a former breeding manager at Janow, who has worked with Arabs for nearly 40 years, said: "We hope and pray that Janow will survive, because privatisation, unlike state ownership, will not guarantee the continuity of the breeding programme.

A rocky market, particularly in the US, largely saturated with good quality horses, has caused problems in recent years and has already persuaded new stud owners to sell their stock and switch to more immediately lucrative businesses. Slovenia's state stud, Lipica, which breeds the Lipizzaner horses, has opened a casino on site and turned its horse pasture into a golf course.

Without any state subsidy, Janow already has to depend increasingly on other enterprises. Stallions are sometimes leased for breeding, and a dairy farm on its 2,000 hectares (5,000 acres) sells milk to shops in th region. Sales of grain and other agricultural produce also support the breeding programme.

Increasingly, hope lies in the domestic market, cashing in on the Poles' worship of the horse as a symbol of life and freedom.

"Rising numbers of nouveau riche Poles are bidding for Arabs," Mrs Pawelec-Zawadzka said.

Janow Podlaski was established by Tsar Alexander I, to replace the huge number of horses killed in the war with Napoleon. Count Julius Dzieduszycki and 100 servants were dispatched to the Arabian desert in 1843, returning two years later with five stallions and three mares. The breeding programme began.

The breeding stock was almost destroyed in both world wars. In the second, fleeing the Russian advance, they were led across Dresden the very night it was bombed. Eighty stallions died.

In 1945 the remaining grooms and horses returned to Poland, finally reaching Janow in 1960. The communist regime allowed it to survive

The stud's director, Marek Trela, hopes that President Aleksander Kwasniewski's presence at this year's auction indicated top-level political support for the continuing protection of the shop window of Polish horses, and a unique cultural monument.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Blair 'should visit Zimbabwe'
fields.body:
Blair 'should visit Zimbabwe'

Southern African leaders may ask Tony Blair to visit to region to hear their concern about Britain's approach to the Zimbabwe land crisis.

President Bakili Muluzo of Malawi, who was appointed with President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa to lobby Mr Blair to "honour Britain's obligations" and fund the land seizures, said yesterday that they might visit London but it might be better he went to Africa.

Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

'Sex slaves' held in Cambodia

The police in Cambodia have taken six east European women aged 18-24 into custody and are investigating whether they have been forced to act as sex slaves for government officials.

The UN human rights office in Cambodia said the women's passports were confiscated when they arrived in Phnom Penh and they were taken every night to a hotel where they were forced to have sex.

Reuters, Phnom Penh

Red Cross staff freed in Georgia

Two international Red Cross workers and their Georgian driver were released in the Panski Gorge in northern Georgia yesterday after being held for a week.

Temur Arabuli, chief of police in the Akhmed district, said the the three were well. He would not say whether a ransom was paid.

AP, Tbilisi

Stasi stirred neo-nazism

East Germany covertly encouraged the growth of new-nazism in West Germany by stirring up anti-semitism and infiltrating far-right groups, according to new evidence from the files of the Stasi secret police.

The newspaper Welt am Sonntag reported that the files and statements by former Stasi officers revealed that the campaign was begun in 1961 to coincide with the trial in Israel of the Adolf Eichmann, who was executed as the Nazi official responsible for implementing the "final solution of the Jewish question".

Tony Paterson, Berlin

Iran silences prize satirist

The Iranian press court jailed Ebrahim Nabavi, the recent winner of an annual award for the best political satirist, at the weekend, together with a young newspaper columnist, Mohammad Qouchani.

Meanwhile it was announced that Fatemeh Faramandpour, editor of the banned weekly Gounagoun, will stand trial on Wednesday.

Reuters, Tehran

Crowned with riches

Ole Andresen, 29, from Oslo, briefly became the world's richest man when his bank mistakenly credited his account with 9,999,999,973,885.24 crowns - about £746bn - the daily Verdens Gang reported.

Reuters, Oslo

webTitle: Comment, Roy Hattersley: After-dinner fees are not corruption

fields.headline: After-dinner fees are not corruption
fields.standfirst:
The standards commissioner should go after the big frauds

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The standards commissioner should go after the big frauds.
fields.body:
It seems that Elizabeth Filkin - the parliamentary commissioner for standards - is determined to prevent members of parliament from receiving payment for corrupt services disguised as fees for speaking engagements. For some time, Ms Filkin's habits of rooting out wrongdoing after she has read about it in the newspapers has caused me concern. The crusade against the Common's corruption should not be driven by publicity-conscious backbenchers making dubious allegations against their opponents. I want the commissioner for standards to squash big frauds, not waste her time on trivia.

No doubt there are members of parliament who would gladly agree to an arrangement in which, having performed an improper service for a company or corporation, they are paid in the pretence that the money is a reward for after-dinner entertainment. Some MPs would accept reduced remuneration if their egos were thus flattered at the same time that their bank balance was improved.

But who are the entrepreneurs who would want to come to such an arrangement? A backbencher cannot ask a question worth a brown envelope stuffed with cloak-room tickets. Any businessman who wastes his money on such an enterprise ought to spend a few pounds on a child's guide to the British constitution. The idea of a scam that requires members of parliament to address the corporation they corruptly serve is wholly implausible.

Since I left the House of Commons, I have spoken for money several times. So I know how such evenings go. Imagine, if you will, that the Solihull Dry Fruit And Raw Vegetable Company is holding its annual dinner for retail customers and wholesale suppliers. The object of the evening is to make everybody feel well disposed towards West Midlands prunes and broccoli. A certain amount of alcohol has been consumed before and during the dinner. As the coffee is served both guests and hosts look forward to consuming a good deal more. Then the chairman of the board rises to introduce Ann Widdecombe who has been engaged, the audience is told, to express her views on the state of the nation and read extracts from her latest novel.

To compensate for the consequent loss of business, Ms Widdecome would have to do a great deal more than ask the secretary of state for trade to reduce the duty on sun-dried tomatoes imported from outside the European Union.

I do not suggest for a moment that Ms Widdecome would be party to such an arrangement. Anyone whose piety extends to the arrangement of a photo call to publicise her admission into the Catholic church would not even consider accepting an improper payment. She was just the first member of parliament who came to mind after a bad night. But I hope the hypothesis serves to illustrate the point. An MP who wants to behave badly will, like any dishonest company director, find easier ways of passing around the used five pound notes than bogus after-dinner speeches.

Now that most of the bad apples have been picked out of the barrel the real problem with both Houses of parliament is institutional rather than individual. I take as my dangerous example the way in which the nation remunerates members of the House of Lords. Peers - rather like doctors at the beginning of the health service - are horrified at the idea of being the state's salaried employees. They (or, to be exact, we) are therefore remunerated with an attendance allowance - a payment received every time a noble head is put round one of the gilded doors that effect entrance into their Lordships' Chamber. It amounts to about £150 a day.

I am sure that there is not a single peer who attends the Upper House of Parliament with the sole purpose of receiving the money. But the idea of payment by non-results does set quite the wrong tone. Writing in this paper a couple of months ago Melvyn Bragg suggested that there should be a salary paid to genuine working peers - a class to which I do not belong. He was excoriated for reasons that ranged from the accusation that he wished to line ermine pockets to the horror that some correspondent felt at the idea of peers being paid like ordinary people. A salary is far better than a system that allows the suspicion - unjustified, I am sure - that from time to time a Baron or Baroness makes a fleeting appearance purely for financial gain.

Their (or our) Lordships regard enquiries into their official finances as a revolutionary impropriety. That is one of the reasons I favour such an investigation. In the meantime I fear that Ms Filkin will go on chasing shadows and all sorts of innocent people will be embarrassed as a result. I am not sure who has been caused most pain by the inquiry into after-dinner speaking fees - Michael Portillo and Charles Kennedy, who accepted them, or Francis Maude, who was never invited to anybody's party.

webTitle: Lost opera staged again after 300 years

fields.headline: Lost opera staged again after 300 years
fields.standfirst: Finally in fashion, the fantastical work Vivaldi buried in a drawer after six disastrous performances
fields.trailText: When Keel Watson takes a deep breath, fills his enormous lungs, and booms out Orlando's magnificent entrance line - "Here is the entrance leading to the dark temple!" - he is singing something which has not been heard on a public stage for some time. Since 1714, in fact, when Vivaldi premiered his own opera Orlando Finto Pazzo. It ran for six disastrous performances before being put in a drawer for three centuries.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
When Keel Watson takes a deep breath, fills his enormous lungs, and booms out Orlando's magnificent entrance line - "Here is the entrance leading to the dark temple!" - he is singing something which has not been heard on a public stage for some time. Since 1714, in fact, when Vivaldi premiered his own opera Orlando Finto Pazzo. It ran for six disastrous performances before being put in a drawer for three centuries.

"It is totally awesome to think when I open my mouth nobody has heard this for almost 300 years," Mr Watson said of the opera, which opened at the Battersea Arts Centre in London on Friday.

Vivaldi is now best known for his Four Seasons, massacred in a million lifts and supermarkets, but he also wrote a wealth of religious and secular music, and several operas.

Orlando was staged when he was musical director of the Teatro Sant Angelo in Venice. It was merely unfortunate that its creator launched the opera just as fantastic plots, sorcery, disguises and magic potions were going out of fashion. A few lines of the plot summary give the flavour of the piece: "As her fairies bewitch Or lando with their songs, Eresilla becomes smitten with Brandimarte, who uses this to rescue Orlando. Grifone tries to capitalise on his reluctant disguise to get closer to Tigrinda by becoming her handmaiden. Origille, now disguised as a man, interrupts them..."

The director, Bill Bankes-Jones, and the conductor, Orlando Jopling, spent months in Italy tracking down and translating the 300-page score and the libretto. "It was a very strange experience," Mr Bankes-Jones said. "We began to feel we were wandering around in somebody else's script."

The quest - the texts were in separate cities - took them to Turin, Elba and Venice. The libretto by Grazio Bracciolo exists in a printed version, the music only in Vivaldi's own handwritten copy.

Eventually they won the approval of the Instituto di Antonio Vivaldi, and were startled to learn that after three centuries of neglect they had only just pipped a rival production, due to be staged in October in Prague.

Transcribing the score had brought them particularly close to the master, Mr Bankes-Jones said. "It was an extraordinarily personal document. It had wine and food stains, and you could see his writing faltering where he was getting tired and stressed. An aria for one of his women singers, which he rewrote twice, has scrawled on top of it: 'If you don't like this I'm never going to write any music again'."

The two men founded Tete a Tete opera on a shoestring three years ago, and have mounted three eclectic seasons at the Battersea Arts Centre.

The first was The Flying Fox, a version of Die Fledermaus which Johann Strauss might struggle to recognise. It was a hit, perhaps because most of the production budget went on a half bottle of champagne per head to encourage the audience to join in and swell the chorus. It got rave reviews, and transferred to the Purcell Room on the South Bank. Last year the company produced Shorts, an evening of new operatic compositions, which was also a box office and critical success and will be revived in a national tour next year.

The company will perform only extracts and one complete act of Orlando rather than the entire opera, which would run for up to four hours. But whatever the reaction of the audience to the new production, the opera's reception can only be an improvement on its last time out.

Orlando Plays Mad is at Battersea Arts Centre, London, for six performances only.

Lengthy waits in the wings

 Another of Vivaldi's works was recently aired for the first time after it was discovered among 80 perfectly preserved manuscripts in the private collection of a family of Piedmontese aristocrats. The unpublished manuscript of L'Improvisataas played in public for the first time in three centuries at Christie's in Rome this summer.

 A collection of 63 Irish jigs written by Beethoven during his "silent period" are to be revived after 170 years of neglect. The folk songs, written in the last 10 years of the composer's life as he struggled against growing deafness, will be adapted for full orchestral performances to be aired next May.

 Manuscripts missing for more than 50 years and containing music by Johann Sebastian Bach and his children were unearthed in the Ukraine last August. The discovery of 5,000 documents, part of the estate of Bach's son Carl Philipp Emanuel, ended a search for the valuable collection which had been lost without trace. The music, among the missing archives of the Berlin Singakademie, founded in 1791, was moved from Berlin to Silesia by the Germans in 1943 to save it from the allies' second world war bombing campaign. Two years later the music fell into the hands of the Red Army and was hidden by the KGB.

 A 30-bar extract from an unknown concert aria by Mozart was heard for the first time in 200 years in London in 1996. The single sheet of music, handwritten by the composer, was performed at Christie's by mezzo-soprano Giselle Minns. The incomplete score was written in the early 1780s while the composer was living in Vienna.

 The art world was recently rocked by the discovery of one of the few surviving works of the 13th century Italian artist Cimabue. The tiny Virgin and Child Enthroned with Two Angels hung unrecognised at Benacre Hall, Suffolk, and was spotted during a routine valuation and acquired by the National Gallery in lieu of £7.2m death duties.

webTitle: Baggage handling tops air travellers' complaint list

fields.headline: Baggage handling tops air travellers' complaint list
fields.trailText: Missing and damaged luggage has become the number one gripe for air travellers, taking over from complaints about delayed flights for the first time in 10 years.
fields.body:
Missing and damaged luggage has become the number one gripe for air travellers, taking over from complaints about delayed flights for the first time in 10 years.

The consumer branch of the civil aviation authority publishes its annual report today which finds passengers have got used to hour-long delays on major airlines but are still angry over the loss of their valuables.

The air transport users council (AUC) says it has seen a 30% increase in complaints about baggage handling and adds that it is yet another example of airlines denying responsibility for causing misery to their customers.

While airlines are quick to own up when they are unable to retrieve luggage from some far-flung destination, passengers have been outraged at the pittance in compensation. If luggage is a little late in arriving, the airlines do not have to pay any compensation.

The AUC says passengers complain that the standard amount they receive, £13 a kilo, barely covers the cost of the suitcase, let alone its contents. One passenger who had to wait a week for his luggage to arrive at his destination received just £50 in compensation.

The worst offenders were Air France and Ryanair.

fields.headline: Protest at Windermere speed limit
fields.trailText: More than 300 boats took to the waters of Windermere yesterday to protest at the introduction of a 10mph speed limit due to come into effect in 2005.
fields.body:
More than 300 boats took to the waters of Windermere yesterday to protest at the introduction of a 10mph speed limit due to come into effect in 2005.

The limit, proposed by the Lake District national park, will ban jetskis and power boats from the lake, the only one in the region open to high-speed craft.

The move has been opposed by speed enthusiasts since it was first proposed eight years ago. They claim that the pleasure of thousands will be wrecked by the limit which will also damage the local economy and ruin boat businesses operating on the lake.

Yesterday's three-mile long armada, with crews waving protest banners, consisted mainly of power boats. "People have voted with their keels to show their disapproval of the decision," said Norman Park, the protest's organiser, who claimed more than 4,000 people had taken part.

The turn-out was three time as big as a rally in April, held three weeks after environment minister Chris Mullin announced he would uphold the limit.

His decision followed a dispute between environmentalists, residents, national park authorities, sport enthusiasts and businesses. The conflict led to a 13-week public inquiry.

fields.headline: Anger at paper's abortion claim
fields.standfirst: Breast cancer link completely inaccurate, protest doctors
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists is considering making a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission over a Mail on Sunday story which claims the college believes that having an abortion can increase a woman's chances of developing breast cancer.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists is considering making a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission over a Mail on Sunday story which claims the college believes that having an abortion can increase a woman's chances of developing breast cancer.

The college is incensed by the front page story, which it describes as "very inaccurate" and "the worst kind of journalism".

"To say we have 'agreed there is a link' is completely false," said Allan Templeton, the college's honorary secretary and chairman of its guidelines development committee. "This story will cause great anxiety, and we probably need to go to the Press Complaints Commission because it is totally inappropriate."

The newspaper claimed that, after analysing US research, based on 28 separate studies, "the RCOG has agreed there is a risk of developing cancer after a termination".

Millions of women would be warned by their doctors of the "worrying link", and the British Pregnancy Advisory Service - the biggest provider of abortions in the country - would echo this anxiety.

Some 180,000 terminations are conducted each year in England and Wales and 12,000 in Scotland, with at least a third of all women having an abortion by the time they reach 45.

But yesterday, the royal college said that, after assessing two reviews of all the available research on the subject, it was still not satisfied there was a link.

"We concluded that the evidence as it stood was inconclusive, that there was no evidence definitely pointing towards a link and that, on the other hand, there was much evidence that suggested there was no link at all," said Professor Templeton.

The Mail on Sunday's story had been based on research, conducted by Joel Brind of the City University of New York, which suggested that women who terminate pregnancies run a 30% greater chance of developing breast cancer.

But Prof Templeton cast doubt on the validity of this work, since it relied on case control studies in which women are required to be honest about whether they had had an abortion.

Separate research has found that women with breast cancer are more likely to admit to having had an abortion, in the hope of shedding light on a possible cause, than healthier women, who are more preoccupied with stigma.

In contrast, studies based on linking national registers of induced abortion with instances of breast cancer were less open to bias, said Prof Templeton. "Two such studies have not shown any significant association," he added.

He continued: "The newspaper has taken one study out of context of the rest of the evidence ... When only those studies least susceptible to bias are included, the evidence suggests that induced abortion does not increase a woman's risk of breast cancer in later life."

The consultant obstetrician also dismissed the newspaper's claims that, while pregnancy protects a woman from breast cancer, having an abortion deals a "hormonal blow" by exposing immature breast cells to carcinogens.

The British Pregnancy Advisory Service, which sees 50,000 women a year, said it was "infuriated" by the claims made in the newspaper.

"This is dishonest journalism and we would certainly support the royal college in pursuing a complaint," a spokeswoman, Ann Ferudi, said.

webTitle: Alarm as jail suicides soar to new high

fields.headline: Alarm as jail suicides soar to new high
fields.standfirst: Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Prison service chiefs have redoubled their efforts to tackle the problem of suicide among inmates, amid worrying signs that the number of deaths is likely to reach record levels this year.
fields.body:
Prison service chiefs have redoubled their efforts to tackle the problem of suicide among inmates, amid worrying signs that the number of deaths is likely to reach record levels this year.

Martin Narey, the prison service's director-general, has voiced his concern that despite a package of measures to prevent acts of self-harm, the number of prisoners who will take their own lives this year looks set to be even higher than last year's record of 91 deaths.

"I regret to say that the number of suicides does not seem to abate," Mr Narey told a conference organised by Unlock, the organisation for ex-offenders. "We have had 53 suicides so far this year, and for reasons none of us under stand, we seem to have more suicides in the later months of the year. The awful truth is we may have more than 91 suicides this year... We have to find some way of tackling this terrible scourge."

Prison service chiefs are alarmed that the rate at which suicides are increasing is outstripping the rise in the prison population. More than 20% of male inmates have tried to take their lives at some point before being sent to prison.

A great deal of effort has gone into developing ways to help inmates who are contemplating taking their own lives. The practice of isolating vulnerable prisoners in "strip cells" has been abandoned, and confidential "listener schemes" run by the Samaritans have been greatly expanded. There are also more "crisis suites" for those who show suicidal signs.

One factor has been the sharp rise in the number of mentally ill people being sent to prison, which has increased seven-fold since the introduction of "care in the community" policies.

Mr Narey said the prison service planned to modernise its health care centres and would end the practice of employing medical officers whose qualifications would not allow them to work as general practioners in the community.

The difficulties facing the prison service over suicides contrast sharply with the progress it is making in combatting illiteracy among prisoners. A major drive to teach reading and numeracy skills has led to 21,000 inmates leaving prison this year with a level 2 national vocational qualification (NVQ) - equivalent to the level achieved by a 14-year-old in school. In the case of many inmates, this would be enough to enable them to break into the job market for the first time in their lives.

More than 62,000 NVQ basic skills units were completed by inmates in the past year, which Mr Narey believes provides further evidence that Britain does not have an "abnormal" prison population but an uneducated one: "They are not stupid or incapable," he said.

Mr Narey also reported that initial research into the effectiveness of sex offender treatment programmes in prisons has proved encouraging. A new study showed that convicted sex offenders released from prison between 1992 and 1996 had reconviction rates that were 59% lower for high risk offenders and 79% lower for low to medium risk offenders if they had undergone a treatment programme before being released.

fields.headline: Speed, bonny boat...
fields.standfirst: ...but not on Lake Windermere, please
fields.trailText: William Wordsworth saw it all coming. Let the railway be extended from Kendal to Low Wood, at the head of Windermere, he warned in a letter to the Morning Post in 1844, and the Lake District would cease to be that wild tract of nature which travellers came to see.
fields.body:
William Wordsworth saw it all coming. Let the railway be extended from Kendal to Low Wood, at the head of Windermere, he warned in a letter to the Morning Post in 1844, and the Lake District would cease to be that wild tract of nature which travellers came to see. "The staple of the district is its beauty and its character of seclusion and retirement," he wrote. If what he called "the imperfectly educated classes" were to come by train in large numbers, the very beauty which drew them would be destroyed. He also feared for what in those days was the peaceful little town of Bowness.

The great poet did not, for obvious reasons, specifically mention speedboats. But for years now, his spiritual heirs have wanted to banish high-speed boats from Windermere by imposing a 10mph limit. They have now won that case, though the ban will not take effect until 2005. Yesterday jet skiers and high-speed boaters were out in force to protest both at the threat to their sport and at the implications for commercial interests around the lake. They mean to go on protesting until the decision is reversed.

This is a dispute where there cannot be compromise. And however much they dislike it, the decision does result from what seems to have been an impeccable process. The Lake District National Park Authority proposed the limit; the relevant authorities were fully consulted; a public inquiry took place; and the Department of the Environment confirmed the inspector's view that high-speed boats should, in effect, be banned. And one does not need to echo the language of Wordsworth to agree that tranquillity ought to come first. The ideal place for this kind of sport is on man-made lakes, of which there are many already around the country and could be more. What a boost it could be to the stricken towns of West Cumbria, now so apprehensive about the future of Sellafield, if a new speedboat capital could be established out there, rather than in Bowness.

fields.body:
Computer Weekly didn't unearth anything (Computer bugs could delay new air traffic control centre, August 11). We volunteered the information about the status of Swanwick. Nor is the project facing further delays.

A year ago there were 1,400 bugs in the system. We've cleared 1,200 and have a detailed programme for the rest. Because of this, we were able to announce last month that the centre would go into operation in January 2002.

David Budgen
National Air Traffic Services

fields.headline: It could be Branson
fields.standfirst: The lottery might benefit from a change
fields.trailText: The National Lottery Commission is a small island in the archipelago of semi-accountable bodies by which we are governed. Its chair is Dame Helena Shovelton, who is also the notional link to public accountability as chair of the Audit Commission. To her and her fellow quangocrats falls, within the next few days, the task of deciding who gets to run the National Lottery from 2001 to 2008.
fields.body:
The National Lottery Commission is a small island in the archipelago of semi-accountable bodies by which we are governed. Its chair is Dame Helena Shovelton, who is also the notional link to public accountability as chair of the Audit Commission. To her and her fellow quangocrats falls, within the next few days, the task of deciding who gets to run the National Lottery from 2001 to 2008. They carry a considerable weight, though their choice is straightforward enough. In one corner there is Camelot, chastened, reformed and, as it would see it, better able than ever to maximise revenues for the good causes. In the other is the consortium led by that remarkable business phenomenon, train operator, airlines magnate and unsparing self-promoter, Sir Richard Branson.

Some (Camelot Group plc among them) say there is a sole criterion for assessing bids: who is likely to produce the golden stream that has fertilised the barren fields of Greenwich, built bridges, towers, science centres - to the tune, so far, of £8bn. We think other factors are relevant too. A not-for-profit bid would fit better with the charitable purposes of many of the recipients; it might mitigate the regressive effects of a game played predominantly by poorer people. Of course Sir Richard (the People's Lottery Ltd) is not entering the lists as a philanthropist. It is a fair assumption that differences between the two bids in terms of return on capital, perhaps also in terms of leakage of punters' money into shareholders' pockets, might not be that great. They are not, however, Tweedledum and Tweedledee. What divides them, at the very least, is history.

The Camelot bid was accepted when the first flush of the Thatcher privatisations had not quite evaporated, when people still believed that private contractors would run railways and keep household water taps flowing. We now know better. The "private is best" model of management has been severely dented in recent years. What we need now is experience of different ways of running services outside the state: how else can we subject contractors to critical comparison? The Branson bid would offer invaluable lessons. Dame Helena should draw on her experience at the Audit Commission. It does its job by contrasting the performance of local authorities one with another. We know what Camelot can do. The People's Lottery deserves a chance to show its mettle.

A not-for-profit bid would fit better with the charitable purposes of many of the recipients; it might mitigate the regressive effects of a game played predominantly by poorer people. Of course Sir Richard (the People's Lottery Ltd) is not entering the lists as a philanthropist. It is a fair assumption that differences between the two bids in terms of return on capital, perhaps also in terms of leakage of punters' money into shareholders' pockets, might not be that great. They are not, however, Tweedledum and Tweedledee. What divides them, at the very least, is history. The Camelot bid was accepted when the first flush of the Thatcher privatisations had not quite evaporated, when people still believed that private contractors would run railways and keep household water taps flowing. We now know better. The "private is best" model of management has been severely dented in recent years. What we need now is experience of different ways of running services outside the state: how else can we subject contractors to critical comparison? The Branson bid would offer invaluable lessons. Dame Helena should draw on her experience at the Audit Commission. It does its job by contrasting the performance of local authorities one with another. We know what Camelot can do. The People's Lottery deserves a chance to show its mettle.

webTitle: Letters: Abuse normally takes place in the home

fields.headline: Abuse: bringing it home
fields.trailText: Most reporting has failed to reiterate that most sexual abuse is perpetrated not by strangers, but by adults well known to children, in positions of trust and within families; by fathers, grandfathers, brothers and uncles and even female relatives on occasion
fields.body:
Most reporting has failed to reiterate that most sexual abuse is perpetrated not by strangers, but by adults well known to children, in positions of trust and within families; by fathers, grandfathers, brothers and uncles and even female relatives on occasion (Chorus of fear and loathing swells, August 12). The media, angry parents, the government and the judiciary would do more to help protect children if they were stressing the need for education, training and support that would effectively equip children with the knowledge, skills and understanding they need to a) recognise the inappropriate behaviour of adults; b) have strategies to counter the coercion of the abuser; and c) know how and where to seek help, in the security they will be believed and listened to.

Many survivors of abuse say that if only they had understood what was happening and knew what to do about it, they may well have been able to stop it happening to themselves and others.

Marion Lovell-Jones, Bristol

Thirty-five years ago, when I was five, I was sent to see the headmistress at my infant school. The young teacher who sent me didn't know how to deal with me telling her, falteringly, of the sexual abuse inflicted on me by my father. The headmistress listened briefly and then spoke, including the words police and prison. In turmoil, it seemed I had only one option. I said I'd made it all up. My memories had to be buried deep and for many years only re-emerged at times of further abuse.

Recent years have allowed me to accept those events. I have periods of deep depression, but have much happiness in my life. Two wonderful sons and a loving extended family and many friends. Even with this, attempting suicide has often seemed the only option.

I hope it's apparent, but penal sentences for paedophilia (which is usually incest), a public register, doesn't help anyone. It's not helpful for paedophiles, society, certainly not little girls and boys, or even a 40-year-old survivor. (PS Childline doesn't have enough volunteers or resources to answer all its calls.)

Name and address supplied

The home is where the vast majority of child sex abuse takes place. By focusing on the "monster" out there, there is a danger that children witnessing this outpouring of public anger will find it even more difficult to disclose what might be happening to them. Such children often feel isolated and fearful of the consequences of revealing that a family member, who might be trusted and loved, is abusing them. These children often love the perpetrators too and cannot contemplate being separated from them, let alone feel responsible for unleashing such potential violence as demonstrated by the vigilantes, fuelled by sections of the press.

We understand the need to keep the spotlight on child abuse, but by demonising certain perpetrators and emphasising the danger without, we run the risk of becoming complacent about the abuse which takes place within families from all backgrounds, races and cultures. Where the emphasis is on the few perpetrators outside the home, safety is an illusion and countless victims remain effectively silenced, unseen and overlooked.

Yvonne Harris and Megan Walters Child counsellors, Manchester

I know not how a person becomes a paedophile, be it by nature or nurture, but all paedophiles once were children. I think those people with their lists should consider the possibility that among them are parents of a boy who will become a paedophile.

Syd Hambly, Manorbier, Pembrokeshire

fields.headline: And making sense of it all
fields.trailText: It is easy from the comfort of a liberal enclave to condemn the anti-paedophile-mob violence (Leader, August 11). But such witch-hunting, however irrational and counter-productive, strikes a deep chord in the national psyche.
fields.body:
It is easy from the comfort of a liberal enclave to condemn the anti-paedophile-mob violence (Leader, August 11). But such witch-hunting, however irrational and counter-productive, strikes a deep chord in the national psyche. All parents want their children to be safe and most know how hard it is to create real security. Mob hysteria is fuelled by the psychological mechanism of projection. The supposed or real offenders are the recipients of all the disappointment which belongs to menfolk in families who consistently let women and children down - from failure to listen, through neglect and abandonment, to physical, emotional and sexual abuse.

Much safer to find scapegoats than confront one's partner or father with years of pent-up rage. Until we have policies which teach young adults relationship and parenting skills and find ways to enhance self-esteem in stressed communities, violent outbursts of mob rule will be likely to occur, even without the help of tabloid papers.

Dr Jeremy Holmes, North Devon J.A.Holmes@btinternet.com

The most profound and long-lasting danger to children in this country comes not from strangers they are unlikely to meet, but from semi-literate parents they see every day, who offer them neither cultural stimulation nor fresh vegetables, who destroy their curiosity about the world before it has begun to develop, and who condemn them to a life lived in ignorance of what that world has to offer them. The vulgarity and bigotry this produces is not confined to working-class estates. It manifests itself among all social groups and income brackets, in town centres, on the Dover-to-Calais ferry, at Wimbledon, at Test matches and increasingly on university campuses.

More importantly, it fills the pages of tabloid newspapers and those TV and radio stations in search of the lowest common denominator. If we feed our children trash they will grow up as trash.

Dr Charles Turner, Warwick University

Vigilante movements arise where there is inadequate enforcement of the law, and a gap between the law and popular conceptions of morality. Both apply to paedophilia in the UK now. The law has not adapted to the hitherto unsuspected scale of the problem or its diverse forms. Enforcement has been erratic, usually too late and too weak. Vigilantes are harbingers of the urgent need for change, and that must involve the police, the paediatricians and the politicians.

JT Winkler, London wink@talk21.com

webTitle: South Africa slow to curb spiralling child sex abuse

fields.headline: South Africa slow to curb spiralling child sex abuse
fields.trailText: The South African government is expected to reject public clamour for a paedophile register in new sex offence legislation aimed at curbing some of the highest rates of child abuse in the world.
fields.body:
The South African government is expected to reject public clamour for a paedophile register in new sex offence legislation aimed at curbing some of the highest rates of child abuse in the world.

Public frustration with the authorities over a series of horrific crimes against children in recent weeks has focused on the case of Phillipus Briel, a convicted rapist due to appear in court today on charges of murdering his 15-year-old step-niece.

Briel, who has been jailed several times for sex crimes, escaped from Sterkfontein psychiatric hospital three months ago. The police made no attempt to look for him even though he was considered a danger to children since committing his first rape at 15.

Briel was living openly with his wife and her niece, Edith Erens. He allegedly strangled the girl before dumping her in a cemetery, and police suspect he raped her several times in the preceding weeks. Edith's murder is one of several cases that have fuelled demands for drastic measures to stop child abuse. Nearly 40,000 assaults on children were reported last year, a fraction of the real total. The rape of girls and boys under seven is sharply higher.

Last week a mother and stepfather were convicted of selling their three young daughters for sex for as little as five rand (50p) a time. One of the girls was seven when she was first raped. Child welfare officials were disturbed that the only person prosecuted for abusing the girls was their stepfather's brother.

On Friday, a Johannesburg school gardener and his assistant were remanded in custody accused of raping a 12-year-old pupil. The same day, two men appeared in court accused of kidnapping five children and imprisoning them in a cave for two weeks.

Among extensive legal reforms to protect children will be a broader definition of rape to include any kind of sexual penetration, including with fingers and objects. And legislation will be changed so as to shield boys as well as girls.

But Joan van Niekerk, chairperson of South Africa's Childline and a member of the committee drafting the legislation, says the law is unlikely to require a register of sex offenders.

"There's all this hype about registers but no one is looking at the hard core issues like who goes on to it and what difference does it make to sexual offences that are committed.

"The evidence from the US is that it [a register] doesn't reduce the number of offences. In a country like ours which has limited resources, why put our money into something that doesn't work simply because it's an emotional response to the problem?"she asked.

One reason a paedophile register is deemed of limited value is that the vast majority of sexual offences against children in South Africa are committed within the family.

Mrs van Niekerk says the more urgent need is to ensure that paedophiles are monitored and treated after their release from prison because so many return to live with the children they assaulted.

The government has already taken some steps to curb child abuse, including lengthening sentences for the rape of minors and introducing special courts in some areas.

Mrs van Niekerk says the new courts are welcome because the judicial system has often proved an added abuse of the victims. The average child sex abuse case takes 18 months to come to trial, and victims are frequently subjected to gruelling court appearances.

But persuading children or their parents to report sexual assaults is difficult. "We see children grossly intimidated by the men in their families who commit these crimes, or gangs. It can be very dangerous for them. We have children and families in hiding because they have reported sexual crimes," Mrs van Niekerk said.

Pressuring magistrates to change their attitudes can also be a problem. Child protection agencies were outraged recently when a retired soldier, Ian Middleton, walked out of court with a fine of 6,000 rand (£600) for luring boys onto his luxury yacht and raping them.

webTitle: More 'ordinary' men than women on TV, says survey

fields.headline: More 'ordinary' men than women on TV, says survey
fields.trailText: Most politicians, sports personalities and business people may well be mostly men, but with women making up 52% of the population, you might expect that television coverage   of ordinary members of the public would be equal.
fields.body:
Most politicians, sports personalities and business people may well be mostly men, but with women making up 52% of the population, you might expect that television coverage of ordinary members of the public would be equal.

But according to a report published today, women are half as likely as men to feature as "ordinary members of the public" on regional news programmes, while 42% of the contestants competing on television quiz shows were women.

The study, Where are the women... in the media?, published by Fawcett, campaigners for equality between men and women, found that 36% of people interviewed for "vox pops" on regional news pro grammes were female. Fawcett also found that women were less likely to be interviewed for "hard" news stories.

The organisation called on women to complain to television companies about the lack of positive female role models on their screens.

webTitle: American fires defy weeks of effort

fields.headline: Blazing trail
fields.standfirst: American fires defy weeks of effort
fields.trailText: Firefighters burnt off scrub to make a firebreak in the Sierra Nevada mountains, but wildfires continued to rage across the western US at the weekend.
fields.body:
Firefighters burnt off scrub to make a firebreak in the Sierra Nevada mountains, but wildfires continued to rage across the western US at the weekend.

There were still 69 sizeable fires in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming, said the national fire information centre.

In Idaho, where fires are burning on more than 400,000 acres, 79 firefighters from Australia and New Zealand were due to join the crews yesterday. Meteorologists predict more hot, dry weather.

AP, Montana

webTitle: Evidence of the Greekness of ancient Macedonia

fields.headline: Suspicious Greeks wreathed in smiles
fields.trailText: A gold wreath 2,350 years old, discovered last month by a farmer in his field outside Salonika, is being brandished by Greeks as the latest evidence of the Greekness of ancient Macedonia, the region now embraced by the Greek province of that name and the independent Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
fields.body:
A gold wreath 2,350 years old, discovered last month by a farmer in his field outside Salonika, is being brandished by Greeks as the latest evidence of the Greekness of ancient Macedonia, the region now embraced by the Greek province of that name and the independent Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

Archaeologists believe the wreath, bearing 30 leaves and two bunches of berries, will provide clues to the worship of Dionysus, the ancient Greek god of wine and revellery. Paintings show gold wreaths being worn by priests attending the often riotous symposia in his honour.

It is the third of its kind to have been found, and similarities between the three suggest that they are the work of the same hand.

The wreath is being cleaned and assessed by conservators at the Archaeological Museum in Salonika, which was besieged at the weekend by Dionysians disappointed at not being allowed to see it.

The director, Chrysanthi Koukouli, said it was likely to be the precursor of a much bigger find in the region. "If it proves to be the spot [in which it originated], then we may well find an important tomb where some distinguished, well-off and reputable Macedonian citizen was buried," he told the daily To Ethnos.

Archaeology has often been used in the row over the right to the name Macedonia.

Although passions have subsided since the former Yugoslav republic's claim to the name filled Greeks with dread that their landlocked neighbour was laying claim to the Greek province - and its port Salonika - the fear remains.

Most liberal-minded Greeks use the title - abbreviated to Fyrom - that the country was given by the UN 1993, and when not referring to its people as Skopjians, after Skopje, the capital, call them Fyromians: a name Slav Macedonians very much hope to drop when the squabble is finally settled later this year.
